title: mum who 16 miscarriages miracle
story: Mum who had  miscarriages has miracle babies after bizarre dream premonitionEmma White, , had given up on getting pregnant again after her daughter Molly Rose was born  years ago, but after a rollercoaster pregnancy last year, she finally gave birth to two healthy girlsEmma had given up hope of having more children Image: PA Real LeByJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A mum who suffered  miscarriages in  years has shared her joy at giving birth to two miracle babies after a rollercoaster pregnancy.Emma White, , had her daughter Molly Rose  years ago and decided not to try for any more children after years of heartbreak. She said: “My miscarriages started when I was just a teenager and I went on to have  of them over the years -all before nine weeks. It was absolutely crushing. But after meeting her husband Joe, , Emmaaposs mind was changed, and she gave pregnancy another go. “I met Joe and he told me straight away he wanted children. I told him no. But then about two weeks later I was so happy, in love and comfortable that all I could think was give me babies!” But Emma, from Kirkby, was once again left devastated after falling pregnant and miscarrying twice. Then, in late , Emma fell pregnant again - this time with twins. But on her birthday, she discovered sheaposd miscarried again at six weeks.For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here She said: After I’d lost the twins I knew that was it. I just couldn’t do it again. Joe completely understood. By pure chance and without trying, Emma found out she was pregnant again just a month later. While she was over the moon, she was terried this pregnancy would end in tragedy again. She recalled: I’d check the toilet every time I went. I was scared to use it, scared to cough, scared of any ache or pain.When she began bleeding and shaking uncontrollably at six weeks in, Emma had familiar feeling and was convinced she had miscarried.She was rushed to Liverpool Womenaposs Hospital for tests and told tofor a scan two days later.Emma said:I got in there, lay down and the sonographer didn’t turn the screen around. I’d been in so many times before and I knew it meant more bad news.  As staff rushed around her, Emma was told she was having an ectopic pregnancy - which is when a fertilised egg implants itself outside the womb.I was told I’d have to have one of my fallopian tubes removed, she said.But after waking up from the operation, Emma learned her pregnancy was normal - and sheaposd simply had a blockage in one of her fallopian tubes. A few days later, a scan revealed another surprise - Emma was carrying quads.Emma said: “I was stunned. I still couldn’t believe it as I was taken off to see a specialist in multiple pregnancies.She walked in and said, ‘So, four babies.’ She showed me another scan image and there they were - four tiny blobs.”However, Emma and Joeaposs joy was short lived when Emma started to bleed heavily at nine weeks. Then a few days later, she stood up and felt something fall out. After being rushed to hospital, doctors confirmed her worst fears - there were no signs of pregnancy.Emma said: I was told it looked like I’d passed the pregnancy. I knew they were right, as I’d seen the babies with my own eyes. I knew they’d gone. After sharing her heartbreak in a Facebook post, a woman approached Emma and offered to be her surrogate.But a few weeks later, she had a dream in which her late grandad, David, appeared and told her she was still pregnant. Emma said: I woke up with a start. My grandad died when I was four and I never have those kinds of dreams.I grabbed a doppler I had on top of the cupboard, held it to my stomach and listened. Sure enough – there was a whooshing sound.Despite Joe’s scepticism, Emma headed to hospital and insisted on being scanned.She said: They must have thought I was mad. I’d been marked down as having lost the babies and there I was, hysterical and crying, saying, aposI’ve had a dream. I’m still pregnantapos.Sure enough, a scan showed Emma was still pregnant with two babies.In an incredibly rare phenomenon, Emma’s quads – two sets of identical twins – had suffered a condition called vanishing twin syndrome twice over.The condition happens when one of a set of twins dies in the uterus and the embryos are normally then reabsorbed into the body.In Emma’s case, she had lost one from each set of identical twins – leaving her with two non-identical twins – and had passed the embryos.Astonished at the news and already  weeks pregnant, she headed home to tell a shell-shocked Joe. From there, Emma described her pregnancy as amazing and was induced at  weeks to give birth to Aurora Azalea, lbs oz, and Ophelia Lili, lbs oz, on  October last year.Emma said: I love being a twin mum. It’s not for everyone, but I cherish every single day. It still feels like a miracle even now the girls are three months old. She added: I just want all the women out there to know thereaposs no shame in it. There are so many of us suffering, thinking weaposre made, terried every time we get pregnant. I hope my story can give some hope.Professor Luciano Nardo, Founder and CEO of NOW-fertility explained what vanishing twin syndrome is.He said: Vanishing twin syndrome is an early pregnancy condition in which one of a set of twins disappears as result of being reabsorbed within the uterine cavity. The outcome is that of a spontaneous reduction of a multiple pregnancy to a singleton pregnancy, as demonstrated on an ultrasound scan.The condition can manest as the disappearance of an early empty gestational sac to that of a sac containing a foetus with or without heart activity. Did you welcome miracle babies into the world  Email jessica.taylor@reachplcAs such, it can be experienced in the form of light vaginal bleeding or spotting throughout the first trimester of pregnancy, or in the form of a miscarriage, which can cause some pelvic painand moderate to heavy vaginal bleeding.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON BabiesPregnancyMiscarriageTwins" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news can-stop-self-isolating-new-"Sajid Javid on self-isolation rules eventually coming to an endByBenjamin LynchSEO Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments As the UK looks ahead to le without the coronavirus, many people will be keen to see an end to restrictions like self-isolation periods.However, cases currently remain high and were recorded as , for January . Plan B measures, meanwhile, expire on January , after Prime Minister Boris Johnsonaposs government already removed restrictions on the wearing of masks in the classroom and ended work-from-home guidance.The end of Plan B has no bearing on rules for self-isolating, though, which has also seen a big change in recent weeks.The period recently saw a cut in the hope that this would address a shortage in NHS staff and teachers.So what are the current rules regarding self-isolation  What are the current rules for self-isolating   People should already begin isolating once they feel they have one of the three following symptoms:a high temperature a new, continuous cough a loss or change to your sense of smell or taste People are recommended to isolatethey have other symptoms as the Omicron iant can appear in people in ious ways. The important thing is to take a test as soon as possible after possible symptoms appear.People are only free from isolation after five full days, so day six after testing, and can only leave quarantinethey test negative on a daily lateral flow test twice consecutively. If you live in the same household as someone with Covid-, you must self-isolate unless you meet one of the following criteria: You are fully vaccinatedYou are under the age of  You are taking part in an approved vaccine trial You are exempt for medical reasonsWhen do self-isolation rules change   The current self-isolation rules in England are now in place until March . The PM has indicated that the government does not expect self-isolation rules to continue past this point. If the data allows for it, the government will also look at scrapping the rules before the deadline.  In the House of Commons, Johnson said: The self-isolation regulations expire on March , at which point I very much expect not to renew them. Indeed were the data to allow, I would like to seek a vote in this House to bring that date forwards. In advance of that, we will set out our long-term strategy for living with Covid-. What to doyou test positive for Covid  According to the NHS, you only need to confirm a positive LFT with a PCR :youaposre applying for a Test and Trace Support Paymentyouaposre eligible for new Covid- treatments youaposre asked to do so as part of research you have a positive rapid lateral flow test on or before day  of arriving in England from outside the UK You can report your positive LFT on the government website, here. Once a person tests positive through a lateral flow test, they must begin isolating for five full days. If you are in the same household as someone, you can reduce the spread of the virus by keeping away from them, keeping shared spaces well-ventilated, surfaces clean and your hands regularly washed. news uk-news cars-flying-london-paris-could-"Flying car gets official air worthiness certicateByRuki SayidConsumer Editor:,  Jan | comments A futuristic flying car has been given the green light to take to the skies.The AirCar, which transforms from a slick four-wheel motor to a sleek aircraft in two minutes, has passed rigorous safety tests with flying colours. It has been awarded an official Certicate of Airworthiness by the Slovak Transport Authority in tests compatible with the European Aviation Safety Agency, meaning it can be flown in EU nations.And there are plans to make it a regular sight in the skies for London to Paris trips, allowing a pilot and passenger to roll off the runway and on to the road. Developed by Slovakian company Klein Vision, it took eight skilled specialists more than , hours to convert design drawings for AirCar into reality. The car-o-plane has completed  hours of flight tests with  takeoffs and landings to be cleared by authorities.  It will now go into production with a launch expected in a year’s time, although there is no price tag yet for the dual-mode vehicle. Sensational footage shows it soaring through the air and then landing and hitting the road looking like a souped-up sports car with a massive spoiler at the back.  The two seater AirCar has a single propellor, uses a BMW engine and can reach a height of ,ft and speeds of mph. Inventor and test pilot Professor Stefan Klein said: “AirCar certication opens the door for mass production of very efficient flying cars.  “It is official and the final confirmation of our ability to change mid-distance travel forever.” Project co-founder Anton Zajac added: “AirCar expands those frontiers, by taking us into the next dimension, where road meets sky. We do have plans to fly to London from Paris in the near future.”  The Slovak Transport Authority said the road-to-air vehicle had been rigorously tested with safety at the heart of the checks. Its director Rene Molnar said: “The transportation safety is our highest priority. “It defines a new category of a sports car and a reliable aircraft. Its certication was both a challenging and fascinating task.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON European UnionBMWCars" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: covid army veterans volunteers jabs
story: Jab volunteer Army veterans wise words for man having his first Covid vaccineFrom helping out at vaccination centres to using their valuable skills to help with logistics, veterans are playing a big part in the fight against Covid-If you haven’t already had your booster, now is the time to do itAdvertorialByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  As the Omicron iant continues to spread rapidly and more people book in their all-important vaccine booster, veterans, along with other volunteers, are doing vital work to help the NHS deliver the programme.Every adult in the country needs a booster dose, soyou haven’t already had yours, now is the time to do it.Just go to nhs.uk covidvaccination to book – and you can also make an appointment for --year-olds and help older teenagers get theirs too.Here we speak to some of the veterans about their work, starting with an ex-soldier who had two words for a man having his first jab which could inspire others to do the same... ‘Evenyou get five people vaccinated, that’s five people who won’t suffer’ Working for the ambulance service, I saw the effects of Covid- during the first wave – almost every patient we took in was ill with the virus. I was part of the Re:Act Disaster Response team who stepped up to help. The NHS was under the cosh at the time and I was part of the RE:ACT Disaster Response team who stepped up to help. I helped build the Nightingale hospitals in Wales and also worked with the local council in Hereford to distribute PPE. Now I’m at the pop-up vaccination centre in Hereford. There are two of us here who are ex-military – the other guy is an ex-submariner so we’ve got a broad range of skills. There’s not a lot that comes across our path that bamboozles us.The first time I volunteered was on a day off from work. We were tasked with letting people know about the vaccination centre, but of course we didn’t want to browbeat them so we let people come to us. Initially people thought we were giving out lateral flow tests – we’d say, No, we’re here for boosters or your first or second vaccination. It was quiet for the first hour, but word obviously spread around Hereford and by the end of the day I’d say we’d vaccinated about  people, from schoolkids upwards. I think . per cent of people were happy to have a vaccination. I thought: Evenyou get five people vaccinated, that’s five people who won’t suffer.” Yes, you might catch it, but you’re much less likely to end up in hospital. When people ask meI think it works, I feel like I can provide the back story for them.We’ve now even had people come in for their first jabs. I asked one, What changed your mind  He said,Omicron, because it’s more infectious’. I just said, “Well done.”So while I don’t strong-arm people, I do tell them, “I think you should get vaccinated. ‘We all need the booster so that le can get back to normal’  I joined the Royal Air Force in  and my last posting was out in Cyprus, but I always wanted to transition to a career in the NHS. Back in October  I joined the East of England Covid- mass vaccination programme and my first role was to provide support in the planning and delivery of large-scale centres, hospital hubs and community pharmacies. Now I’m working as the children’s project manager, leading and coordinating plans. This involves collating, analysing and improving plans, reporting to the programme director and the national team, using my past experiences to collaborate, advise and implement processes.  I’m good at seeing a problem and thinking outside the box to solve it. I can get parachuted into a project within the Covid- programme and am able to run with it. Every day is dferent, but that doesn’t faze me. I’m very adaptable and flexible – and I’ll give  per cent to achieving the common goal. Working with other people from the Forces means there’s a great sense of camaraderie. We share the same service ethos. If there’s a deadline, we’ll just knuckle down and get the job done. This is not a - job. Even though I might have to get up at .am to jump on a work call, I have no problem with that. I was motivated to join the Covid- programme by my sense of duty, and I’m really proud to be part of it. I have a passion for helping people and making sure things are completed to the highest standard. This gives me a real sense of achievement. I like being able to make a dference. The public response to getting boosted has been great, but there is still a long way to go. I believe the Get Boosted Now campaign is so important because we need to protect ourselves, the vulnerable and the future generations. We also need to get everyone boosted so we can get le back to normal as soon as possible. ‘One of my ex-soldiers gave me the Covid- jab’  I was  when I joined the Navy as a medic. It was the year after the Falklands War and I thought I’d like to get involved in something for the service of the country – to do what’s necessary when the time comes. As a Navy medic I was trained to deal with trauma from the very basic things up to the most drastic ones you could think of, like gunshots and traumatic amputations. After  years, I left in  to join the Army, then in  I moved to the NHS. During the pandemic I was initially asked to oversee the distribution of PPE. There were shortages across the board, and having worked overseas with the Royal Marines, my logistics knowledge came to the fore. I could make sure community midwives and health visitors had what they needed. In some cases this entailed doing the deliveries myself in the van!  For me, the pleasure in the role was being able to provide medical staff with the assurance that they would have the equipment they needed. I felt I was making a real dference. When the time came to get my Covid- jab, it was one of my former soldiers who gave me it. That was very impressive because when I met him he was , wide-eyed and fresh out of the box. When I next met him he was teaching the volunteers and St John’s Ambulance staff how to administer the vaccine. I was full of admiration for him. He’d stepped up as a young man and was teaching much more mature iniduals. But I wasn’t surprised – that’s what we expected our troops to do: step into the breach, wherever the breach happens to be. You can’t praise the veterans highly enough for getting involved in the vaccine campaign. They will serve their community in whatever circumstances, whether it’s dficult or easy. You’ve got a group of people who drop everything as soon as they’re asked, regardless of what their family commitment might be, and go and do the job. I don’t think there is a better resource for the country to draw upon.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON British ArmyRoyal Air ForceNHSRoyal MarinesFalklands WarNigel JonesJake WadeHelen RobertsHospitalsSoldiersArmed forcesTeenagersThe FalklandsMost ReadRecommended

news uk-news covid-rules-masks-passes-planb-"Sajid Javid says UK should be ‘proud’ as Plan B ltedByHarry ThompsonTrends Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsPrime Minister Boris Johnson announced last week the governmentaposs plan to ease the UK away from the Plan B Covid restrictions that have been in place since mid-December to tackle Omicron.The announcements will have come as welcome news to some, particularly those working in jobs that have been hampered by the aposlockdown liteapos that has seen huge drops in footfall in the hospitality and nighttime industries. Others, however, will be less enthusiastic about the upcoming changes - with many of the countryaposs vulnerable still forced to shield from the virus. But what does the governmentaposs exit strategy from Plan B actually include, and when will the ious rule changes be coming into effect  Thursday, January   Two key changes are planned to come into place this Thursday. Face masks indoors People have had to wear face coverings in certain indoor settings - including public transport - since the introduction of Plan B in December, but as of Thursday this will no longer be a legal requirement. All kinds of indoor facilities have required the wearing of masks inside, from cinemas and theatres to indoor sports facilities and shops. The government does however still recommend people wear face coverings in crowded places, especially when filled with strangers. NHS Covid passes Indoor venues of more than  people like nightclubs and other late-night venues - as well as outdoor events for more than , people - have all needed an NHS Covid pass to be shown upon entry. The same has gone for any event with over , attendees.As of Thursday this is no longer going to be a legal requirement, although venues can use their own discretion and request entrants show a passthat is their preferred policy. The introduction of the law in the first place was controversial, with a -strong Tory revolt taking place at the time, leading to substantial pressure ever since for the Prime Minister to do away with the measure. Rules already changed Work from home guidance, which has dominated the working lives of many since well before Christmas, was lted last week. This was brought to an end when the official government advice for people living in England to work from home wherever possible was officially lted, with Johnson encouraging people to get in touch with their employers to discuss the next steps for ing to workplaces and offices. Ahead of the general end to mandatory mask-wearing, last Thursday also saw an end to school children needing to wear masks in classrooms with them having worn them since coming back to school after Christmas. Some rules remain The latest announcement last week saw no change to rules around travel to the UK, with people still needing to take a test within  hours of theirto the UK. There is also no change to the legal requirement to isolate for at least five daysyou test positive for the virus. The minimum time people needed to isolate has recently been shortened drastically, with people no longer needing to stay home for the full  daystheytwo negative lateral flow tests on two consecutive days after the fth day of isolation. title: currys driver sacked flirty texts
story: Currys driver sacked for flirty texts to customer as he claims she was begging for itThe delivery man has been caught out after two women complained of his disgusting behaviour saying he was using Currys like TinderRyan Sagar with his fiancee Kacey Wheeler Image: Kennedy News and MediaByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A Currys driver has been sacked after sending a customer flirty texts and claiming she was begging for it.The delivery man was caught out after messaging who he thought was Kacey Wheeler, , after delivering a washing machine in Bradford on January , when it was actually her fiance. Currys say their investigation into the incident confirmed aposJordanapos - a name the driver made up - breached their code of conduct and heaposs been sacked by their delivery partner.Since social media posts by Kaceyaposs partner Ryan Sagar went viral, another woman - Jessica Hickling - has come forward to claim she was targeted by the same man after delivering a fridge freezer on December .Jessica, , was left unsettled when Jordan kept smiling at her and askedshe lived alone, before sending messages after leaving askingshe liked her new fridge andhe could keep her number. She now fears Jordan knows her phone number and address after using Currys like Tinder. Jessica, from Newsome, West Yorks., said:I thought he was helpful but after I got the message I thought it was a bit creepy he went out of his way to help me. He askedI live here on my own and I thought that was a weird thing to ask. I told him aposno, with my son, but heaposs at his dadapossapos. It was strange. I didnapost think too much of it but when I saw the text message, it creeped me out because heaposs been in my house and knows where I live. Heaposs now got my number and knows I live on my own as well. When I got the text, straight away I thought nobody  knew Iaposd had the fridge delivered so it had to be him sending the message. Itaposs worrying because thereaposs a possibility he could come back. But Jordan has since complained he was set up by Kacey and that the messages have destroyed his relationship.  Jordan said: Iaposve got a bird. My relationshipaposs been destroyed over this. Iaposve lost everything overnight. Iaposve been set up. Iaposve gone to this young girlaposs house in Bradford and obviously, sheaposs wanted it. Sheaposs been flaunting it. We put two items in her house and she askedwe were down for installation and I said no, then she askedI could come back after work and install it, but I said aposno, not reallyapos. I got in the van and I told my mate what she said, and he told me to message her this and that. So I started messaging her and we made up the name [Jordan]. She definitely wanted me to get in touch. She wanted it. She was begging for it. How did she expect me to come back after workI didnapost have the number to contact her  My girlfriendaposs seen it and obviously itaposs not good. I said it was a laugh with the lads in the van, but sheaposs not forgiven me yet. If she wasnapost flaunting it like that, I wouldnapost need to [text her].  Ryan, , made headlines last week after his texts posing as Kacey went viral. Jordan bragged about earning £, in the messages and claimed he could be Kaceyaposs apossugar daddyapos. Ryan then revealed himself and complained to Currys. Kacey, from Bradford, West Yorks., said: Ryanaposs dadaposs a plumber and heaposs renovated the house from as old as it can be to brand new, so I wouldnapost need him to do it. I canapost believe it. Heaposs disgusting, that guy. I canapost believe heaposs got the cheek to sit and say that. Maybe this is what heaposs said to his girlfriend to win her back. I feel sorry for her. I literally had a beige jumper on and leggings, so I couldnapost have been more dressedIaposd have tried. Heaposs obviously a creep. I couldnapost care less what he says. The fact heaposs gone into another girlaposs house and done the same thing, that just says it all. When asked about his texts to Jessica, Jordan said: I worked with someone dferent then. It was me messaging but it was a laugh. We were just messing about in the van as lads do. Nobodyaposs saying that itaposs alright. It is what it is. I wouldnapost do it again. I wasnapost trying to make them uncomfortable. Currys have confirmed Jordan was working for a delivery partner contracted to drop off their products and theyaposve sought to reassure customers drivers will face the sackthey breach their conduct rules. A Currys spokesperson said: We were very concerned to learn of the experiences of Ms Wheeler and Ms Hickling. Weaposre directly in contact with them and our immediate priority is to ensure their concerns are addressed. We recognise the privilege and responsibility that comes with delivering to our customersapos homes and we expect all delivery crews, including our delivery partners, to treat our customers with the utmost respect. We launched an immediate investigation into the matter and can confirm the inidual involved is no longer delivering for Currys or working for our delivery partner. Weaposre reinforcing our robust procedures with delivery partners to ensure the highest standards of conduct we expect are always met. title: dads worst nightmare after finding
story: Dads worst nightmare after finding twin son floppy in his cot after strokeRonnie Kerman became one of the UKs youngest stroke victims when his mum Louise found him unconscious and rushed him to hospital in Hull, East YorkshireRonnie Kerman with his twin brother Robert Image: Hull Daily Mail   MEN MediaByAditi RaneLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Jan | commentsA mum and dad experienced every parentaposs worst nightmare when they discovered their -month-old son floppy and unconscious in his cot. Ronnie Kermanaposs parents were warned they might lose their son after doctors confirmed he had suffered a stroke. Mum Louise immediately knew something was wrong when she found the tot unconscious in his crib in February . She would usually be greeted by the sight of Ronnie, who has a twin brother named Robert, standing at the edge of his bed waiting to be picked up.But this time, he was laying on his back with the left-side of his body aposall floppyapos, reports Hull Live.Louise and dad Phil rushed him to Hull Royal Infirmary and a CT scan revealed a black mark on the -month-old toddleraposs brain. The couple were then urged to take Ronnie to Leeds General Infirmary for treatment.  Ronnie was diagnosed with an Optic Pathway Glioman and Neurofibromatosis Type , which caused Ronnie to become completely blind. He has also since been diagnosed with Moyamoya disease which is caused by a blocked artery in the brain. The brave tot underwent several brain surgeries for the cancerous tumour inside his brain in  and . After a promising response at first, things took a sharp turn when Ronnie became allergic to his chemotherapy and his parents were told to prepare for end of le care. Phil said: When the doctors spoke about palliative care, I just couldnapost believe it. I was really shocked because Ronnie had been doing so well and we were told the tumour on his brain had shrunk. But the tumour had grown a little bit and they said there was nothing  they could do. I just said to the doctor aposyouaposve got to do something, youaposve got to help him and save his leapos. Doctors then put Ronnie on a daily chemotherapy treatment called Trametinib which he can take orally. He is the youngest patient to have been administered the treatment. Phil said the treatment has been absolutely fantastic and Ronnie is now approaching his sixth birthday. He added: I couldnapost ask for anything more really. He is just a little superstar, we never thought it would be this way. He can even aposbum shuffleapos from the living room to the kitchen. Even though he canapost see, he knows where he is and where he needs to be. Itaposs fantastic. Ronnie has also benefited greatly from sensory play using sensory boards and playing in the water. He has grown fond of swimming and attends weekly swimming lessons. Phil added: Heaposs a cheeky little boy now and he is quite independent. He knows what he wants and likes. He enjoys music, everything from nursery rhymes to rock music like AC DC. Despite his astronomical progress, medical complications are not uncommon and hospital visits are still a regular occurrence for Ronnie. The youngster will visit Hull Royal Infirmary next week to have his feeding tube replaced and treat his tooth decay, which is a side effect of his chemotherapy. To help him lead a better quality of le, David Freer decided to fundraise £ for any additional sensory equipment that Ronnie would need.David, who volunteers at Le for a Kid, will be doing the Jane Tomlinson Hull K run in June along with his dog Lewis, who is an NHS therapy dog, to raise the money for Ronnie.Phil said: I have known of David because he comes with Lewis at the Hull Royal Infirmary, so Ronnie has previously met David. Itaposs really amazing what people can do from the goodness of their heart. I canapost thank him enough.Contributions to Davidaposs fundraiser for Ronnie can be made on his JustGiving page.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON CancerHealthMiracle babiesBabiesStroketumourTwins" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news deaf-dog-taught-sign-language-"Deaf dog Rocco: A day in the leByKatie L Wilson:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsRescue dog Rocco understands sit, stay and good boy in sign language after being taught by staff at his rescue centre. He lost his hearing after suffering an ear infection but has learned to respond to hand signals. Staffordshire bull terrier Rocco, seven, was initially handed into rescuers in  but was quickly rehomed with new owners. However when one of the owners died and the other became seriously unwell he ed to the Llys Nini Animal Centre in Penllergaer, near Swansea. Centre worker Sally Humphries said: His new owners were really lovely and Rocco took to them straight away.  I remember laughing at the fact he didnapost want to come and say goodbye to me when I dropped him off. He stayed by their side like heaposd known them all his le. When Rocco ed, staff learned that he was completely deaf, so they started teaching him sign language.  Sally said: He reads our hand signals and body language as a way of telling what weaposre asking for. For example, thumbs up means good boy. Most dogs are more in tune with our body language than our constant chitter chatter so itaposs not that tricky for a deaf dog to learn. Itaposs all about consistency and making sure you choose a simple sign for each behaviour that you are trying to teach, so itaposs as clear as possible for them to understand.Rocco is a wonderful example of just how resilient animals can be and proof that you can definitely teach an old dog new tricks.Staff hope the new skill will help Rocco find a forever home soon. title: dont surprised report nusrat ghani
story: Don’t be surprisedreport into Nusrat Ghani ‘Muslimness sacking is a whitewashNusrat Ghani says she was sacked in  because her ‘Muslimness’ Image: Chris McAndrew   UK Parliament opinionByDarren Lewis:,  Jan As a reporter on my local paper, I took a call from a Tory councillor. It was during the Nineties and he was a governor at a nearby school. We arranged to meet to discuss a story. My paper didn’t have picture bylines at the time but I knew who he was. We arranged to meet at a town hall but as I approached him a look of horror swept over his face. I stuck out a hand to introduce myself.“Hi, I’m Darren, good to meet you.” I said. “Oh,” he replied. “You don’t sound black on the phone ”The meeting didn’t last long.  I remembered it while listening to the preposterous Tory MP Michael Fabricant over the weekend. He was speaking after ex-minister Nusrat Ghani claimed she was told by party Whips that she was sacked in  because her ‘Muslimness’ made colleagues uncomfortable. Chief Whip Mark Spencer has rejected the claim as “completely ” and “defamatory”. Fabricant took to radio station LBC, saying: “I think the whole thing actually stinks. She’s hardly someone who is obviously a Muslim.”  Where to start  To dismiss blond wig-on-a-stick Fabricant as a ludicrous character Harry Enfield or Ricky Gervais would have been proud of actually allows the Lichfield MP off the hook. You can make up your own mind as to the legitimacy of Ms Ghani’s claim. It wouldn’t surprise anyone, however, that it has erupted within a party whose leader compared Muslim women to letterboxes and bank robbers. Or that Downing Street has confirmed Ms Ghani complained to Prime Minister Boris Johnson directly – two years ago.  Johnson, she claimed, urged the former junior minister to use the formal complaint process which, with this regime, is probably a bit like going to the policeyou have an issue with a colleague within the mafia. Don’t be fooled into thinking the inquiry called by Johnson on Monday morning is anything other than a welcome opportunity to keep the upcoming Partygate report from Sue Grayoff the front pages. If Johnson really does take the issue seriously, why didn’t he bang his fist on his desk and order the inquiry back then, when Ms Ghani told him  In any case the inquiry won’t be independent - even though civil servants are supposed to be. It will be conducted by the Cabinet Office – the people who work for the PM. Don’t be surprised when it turns up a nothing-to-see-here whitewash. The stag do that has been Johnson’s premiershiphas shown us a party stuck in the past. A nationalistic, flag-waving regime, replete with Benny Hill-type chancers pining for the days of the Empire and a time when you could say anything you wanted, regardless of any offence caused. It comes from the top. We shouldn’t be surprised it is rotten from the core. title: expert gives cause mystery dog
story: Expert gives cause of mystery dog illness killing thousands of UK sea creaturesMarine biologist David McCreadie shared his views on the mysterious illness that is affecting hundreds of dogs and killing wildle along the coast of YorkshireMarine biology expert David McCreadie gives his opinion Image: David McCreadieByJoanne WelfordLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Jan | commentsA mysterious illness that is impacting dogs and killing thousands of sea creatures along the British coast has been explained by an expert. David McCreadie believes a process called dredging is behind the deadly illness which has had a devastating effect on wildle in recent months. Hundreds of pet pooches have reportedly been struck down after walks on beaches along Yorkshireaposs coast over the past few weeks. Meanwhile dead crabs and rotting lobsters have been littering the coastline between Marske and Saltburn in North Yorkshire, while piles of crustaceans have been spotted in Seaton Carew and Seaham in County Durham. Mr McCreadie said he saw a vessel dredging off Teesmouth near the North Yorkshire coast in late September.The former senior lecturer in marine biology and oceanography believes this process has released historic toxins from the bottom of the sea, reports Yorkshire Live.It comes after a fisherman reported that there are no crabs or fish for miles off Yorkshireaposs coast and that he has to survive off just £ a month.  Investigators have ruled out dredging as the cause behind these events but Mr McCreadie claims a two-week operation unearthed historic toxins off Teesmouth and the dredged material was dumped three or four miles off the coast. He has called for more samples to be taken by the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairsand for Government labs to test specically for cyanide and deadly dioxins. The expert, also a member of the British Divers Marine Le Rescue, has been keeping an eye on reports of dogs falling ill after walking on the beaches which some believe is linked to the piles of dead sea creatures washed up on the shores. Mr McCreadie said he is . per cent certain that the dredging operation unearthed toxins left behind from a century of dumping in the Tees river. In November , the Environment Agency rejected chemical pollution as a likely cause and investigators have said dredging, sewage and undersea cabling activity is not to blame either. More than , potential chemical contaminants have been screened and inspectors said no anomalies that could lead to an event of that scale have been found. Defra is now leading the investigation and said samples of dredged material had to meet high standards before it could be disposed of at sea. A spokesperson said Environment Agency tests on crabs and lobsters also ruled out chemical pollution. title: family finds scorpion snuck bags
story: Family finds scorpion had snuck into bags in Costa Rica  days after ing to UKThe stowaway scorpion was found in their kitchen in Winchester, Hants., after it snuck into one of the suitcases while they were traveling in Costa Rica and survived the -hour and -minute flight back to the UKA family were shocked to find this scorpion has snuck into their suitcase from Costa Rica Image: RSPCAByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsA family were shocked to find a scorpion had got in their luggage while they were in Costa Rica. To make things worse, they didnapost find the pincer-wielding arachnid for  days. The stowaway scorpion was found in their kitchen after it snuck into one of the suitcases they were in the Central American country. It miraciously survived the -hour and -minute flight back to the UK, but remained undetected for a week-and-a-half before the family spotted it and alerted the RSPCA. The creatures - which have venom in their sting tails - can kill humans. The family from Winchester, Hants., had been holidaying in Costa Rica which is , milesaway.  An RSPCA spokesperson said: This scorpion departed from Costa Rica and arrived at a house in Winchester. The shocked family found him in their kitchen  days after theyaposd ed from vacation Heaposs now safe and in expert care. One animal lover urged travelling Brits to check their belongings for hidden creatures when they pack to come home and said: Poor little thing, glad heaposs safe now. for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email.Itaposs really not that dficult to check shoes and clothes when packing. Just allow a little more time for it is all, donapost leave it until the very last minute.Last year, a plane was forced to turn back mid-flight after a cat reportedly attacked the pilot.The Sudan to Qatar Tarco Airlines flight encountered a problem roughly  minutes into its journey. A cat, which is thought to have got aboard during cleaning, seemingly woke up during the flight and attacked crew members.  And in  , a woman ended up making two trips to France toa stowaway dormouse to its home. The rodent got in Dr Sue Collard’s car as she drove back from her holiday home in Normandy in April.Ten days later, she spotted it snfing some pears and caught it in a homemade trap, but it escaped. After recapturing it, she drove back to the hamlet of Saint-Gervais-des-Sablons last month but the dormouse would not budge. She then set off for France again earlier this month and finally had success after forking out £ on ferries and petrol. news uk-news five-signs-harrys-frosty-relationship-"Prince Harry files claim over police protection for familyByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan | comments After quitting the Firm and moving to America to start a new le, Prince Harry aposs relationships with some of the royals have been rocky. And the bond with his dad Prince Charles is one that has especially felt the strain of late. Last year, in his bombshell interview with Oprah Winfrey, Harry accused his dad of cutting him off financially and not taking his calls. In addition, Harry has also appeared on the Apple TV series The Me You Canapost See, where he spoke about the royalsapos total neglect and the Armchair Expert podcast, where he lashed out at Charlesaposs parenting. And just last month, one report claimed relations between the pair were at aposrock bottomapos and that they were barely speaking. However, with the turn of the year, there have been claims of several olive branches, which appear to show that their icy relationship may be starting to thaw... Fatheraposs pride One of the first signs that Harry and Charlesapos relationship could be improving was just days into the New Year. It came in an essay that Charles wrote for Newsweek, where he issued a call for urgent action to save the environment.In the piece, he praised both Prince William and Harry for their work in raising awareness of the issue.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.Months earlier, at her speech at the Cop climate change summit in Glasgow in November, the Queen name-checked both Charles and William for their work in saving the environment, but there was no mention of Harry. However, in the essay, Charles spoke about how he was proud of both William and Harry for having recognised the threat of climate change. He said: Most recently, my elder son, William, launched the prestigious Earthshot Prize to incentivise change and help repair our planet over the next ten years by identying and investing in the technologies that can make a dference. And my younger son, Harry, has passionately highlighted the impact of climate change, especially in relation to Africa, and committed his charity to being net-zero. Enjoyable video calls Shortly after the Newsweek essay was released, the Mirror revealed that Charles had held several “good-natured and enjoyable” video calls with Harry. Sources close to Charles said that despite reports of the two not speaking, Charles and Harry have been on “a journey of rediscovery” in terms of their relationship. One said: “The Prince of Wales has spoken to his son frequently in recent months. He loves him very much, as he does both his children, and he looks forward to them being able to spend time together in the near future.” Missing grandchildren And not only does it appear that Charles is missing his son and daughter-in-law Meghan, he is also desperate to see their children.Charles hasnapost seen two-year-old Archie since the family moved to Calornia and he is yet to meet his seven-month-old granddaughter Lilibet. One source said: “The Prince of Wales has been saddened that he hasn’t had the opportunity to spend time with his grandchildren, which he really does miss. “He is a fantastic grandfather and loves playing the role immensely and it’s certainly fair to say he feels there is something missing from his le without the ability to get to know Harry’s children. Invitation to stay Meanwhile, another olive branch Charles has extended to his youngest son is an invitation to stay with him when he and his family next visit the UK. The offer of bringing the family together for the first time since Harry and Meghan decided to quit their royal roles and set up home in Calornia was made by the heir in the lead up to Christmas, it is understood. But Charles’s good-natured plan, in an attempt to heal the rt between him and his son, has been thrown into doubt after Harry suggested awould come at “too great a personal risk” due to his security situation.  Harry claims he is “unable tohome” after a decision following his exit from the royal family stripped him of his right to personal security provided by the Met Police. He has since decided to sue the British government by applying for a judicial review against the decision, which could see him face the Home Office at the court.Meanwhile, a report today suggests Charlesapos invitation comes amid fears over what Harryaposs memoir, due out this year, will say about Camilla, the Duchess of Cornwall.Those fears are said to revolve around Harryaposs recollections of Camillaaposs entry into the Royal Family and how her romance with his father damaged him from a young age. Secret talksHowever, itaposs also said that Harry himself reached out to his dad with the pair having secret talks to heal their rt before the Queenaposs Platinum Jubilee celebrations. A royal insider told the Sun : “There has been a definite thaw in relations between Harry and Charles. They are on much better terms and have been having friendly chats and video calls.“It has been suggested to Harry he may live to regret any lingering family bitterness, and he has taken that on board. “There is a feeling he is coming back more into the fold and wants to be closer to his family.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Prince HarryPrince Charles, Prince of WalesRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: girl 14 dances way heaven
story: Girl, , dances her way to heaven as brave teen loses rare cancer battleLily Douglas, , from Perth in Scotland, has tragically died after a battle with a five-year battle with a rare and aggressive form of cancer called Ewing Sarcoma that attacks bone and its surrounding tissuesLily Douglas, , from Perth in Scotland, tragically passed away last night after a five-year battle with cancer Image: Jane DouglasByKathleen SpeirsReporterRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A brave teen hasdanced her way to heaven after her tragic death from a rare cancer, her heartbroken mum has said.Lily Douglas, , from Perth in Scotland, bravely battled Ewing Sarcoma - a rare form of cancer that attacks the bones and surrounding tissues - for five years. Her grief-stricken mum Jane shared the devastating news in a social media post yesterday.She was participating in a potential breakthrough drug trial at Newcastleaposs Royal Victoria Infirmary when she suffered a brain bleed and died, the Daily Record reports.After being admitted on January , doctors told Jane they were unsureLily would last the night. Butshe did survive, they didnapost know what damage would be done. Lily - who won the Teenager of Courage prize at the Pride of Scotland Awards - managed to open her eyes on Sunday and spoke with her mum, ate some food and even checked her phone for messages. But her condition worsened and she passed away at .pm last night, with her mum confirming she had danced her way to heaven.Announcing the tragic news on Facebook, Jane wrote: Her heart failed but she was on the sofa at home, cuddled into me where she wanted to be.She will leave a massive hole in my heart. If love could have saved her she would have lived to a million years old. She is at peace and is finally in no more pain. Even with cancer, Lily lived her best le and was loved by everyone. I hope I made her proud. I was her mum, we were a great team. Please keep Leon in your prayers, he will need lots of love and support. Itaposs not goodbye, she will be waiting on me. Itaposs only time that will keep us apart. She looks so beautul and peaceful and even died with her beautul, blonde hair. Thank you all for your love and support. I could not have done this without you all. Lilyaposs inspirational fight saw her scoop a Pride of Scotland Award last year where she was crowned Teenager of Courage. Her tenacity did not go unrecognised by a host of famous faces. Strictly Come Dancing icon Dame Arlene Phillips built a strong bond with the hero schoolgirl. Lilyaposs bravery even inspired the TV star to take part in last yearaposs Iaposm A Celebrity. . . Get Me Out Of Here! Arelene, , said on the show: One of the bravest, most fearless girls is a little girl I know called Lily Douglas, sheaposs so fearless. I thought, here I am afraid of so many things. What better way can you push yourself than to do something like this  Closer to home, Lewis Capaldi gave Lily aposthe best day of her leapos when he invited her on stage when he performed at TRNSMT in .The Someone You Loved singer sent a video message to Lily at an awards ceremony before striking up a friendship over Instagram. He invited her and pal Yasmin Chan to come meet him in the artist village backstage - where he surprised her with the chance of a letime to hang out side stage. The pair also wowed online followers when they took part in a popular TikTok challenge together. Gorgeous Lilyaposs talents didnapost end at dancing. In October last year she took to the catwalk, modelling prom dresses alongside Miss Scotland, Claudia Todd who hailed the teen as aposbeautul and talentedapos. Loved ones paid tribute to Lily in their droves hailing her as aposan amazing girl apos with aposa beautul heartapos. One said: Omg Jane, I am devastated for you, she was a beautul girl with a beautul heart. Another added: Jane I am so so heartbroken for your loss, she was such an amazing girl. A third said: Jane I am so so sorry. Lily was a beautul, special little girl and she touched so many lives. I am heartbroken for you all. Much love. title: grans flat cold grandkids visit
story: Picture by Tim Merry" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _JS.jpg" width"" "" Grandmother Diane Skidmore’s flat is so cold her grandchildren can’t even visit Image: Tim MerryByLucy ThorntonNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsGrandmother Diane Skidmore’s flat is so bitterly cold her grandchildren can’t even visit. The -year-old admits her home leaves all her visitors shivering and her family worried she’ll get pneumonia. But Diane says these are the s she has to go, to keep those rising energy bills down. The mum-of-six and gran to seven, has seen her energy bills soar by % in recent months from £ to £. Speaking from her frosty ground floor flat in Tulse Hill, South London, she said: “A neighbour came in yesterday and I noticed she was shivering. “I said ‘I’m really sorry. Let’s move into the living room’, where the temperature was not much dferent but the sun was shining in.” The Mirror is calling for VAT on energy bills to be scrapped as rocketing prices look set to push millions into poverty. Former NHS worker Diane gets £ to live on after her rent is paid from her state pension and is dreading the energy bill rises to come.“I live in the cold. My hands are freezing at the moment. Quite often my nose is cold like a dog’s. My kids are worried I will get pneumonia. “My daughters won’t bring the kids around because my house is so cold. They worry about me getting diseases or stuff too. “ Since the pandemic Diane only ventures out to get her prescriptions because she is asthmatic and has been shielding so does not spend any money on luxuries. “I’m very worried the bills are going up because I can’t live any more frugally than I already live,” she explained. “I already don’t turn the heating on most days and I never ever turn the heating on at night. “On the very coldest days I put it on at pm and put the kitchen timer on for half an hour. There is a cold patch around about pm. “I’ve got a bath but I don’t do that a lot to be honest. I’m very low maintenance. “I mostly eat vegetables. I’ve got a gas kettle because electric kettles take up so much energy. “I’m just worried it’s going to be horrible. I have to have faith. I’m not the only one with trouble going on, they have to come up with a solution.”  Diane says she has tried other ways to heat her flat by blocking all the air vents and putting a big thick heavy curtain up but said it just causes condensation and black mould. “But I refuse to moan about it because when I was young we didn’t have gas central heating, when it got cold you just put a jumper on or do some exercise,” she said. But then admits: “At night it is very cold in here. “At the moment it’s only one degree at night and I can feel my head and my nose are absolutely verging on damp. I have to go down the bed under the sheets to get warm. “My old neighbour, who died, had a ‘noddy’ hat which he kept on all through winter. He used to sleep in it too. “Maybe I should get a hat.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSPensionsEnergy billsState pension" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: inside prince andrews raunchy topless
story: Inside Prince Andrews raunchy topless holidays with infamous NyLon gangPrince Andrew was reportedly ordered by the Queen to dump his pals and their "murky world of cocaine, crime and casual sex" before he damaged the Monarchy foreverPrince Andrew on-board a yacht off the coast of Phuket in Thailand Image: Eliot Press   ELIOTPRESS   MEGAByDanya BazaraaSenior News ReporterRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan Prince Andrew was reportedly warned he must cut ties from a gang of friends amid fears for the royal reputation as he partied in nightclubs more than  years ago.A  article by the Sunday People told how Prince Andrew was ordered by the Queen to dump his pals and their murky world of cocaine, crime and casual sex before he damaged the Monarchy forever. It spoke of the Queen and Prince Philipaposs fury after Andrew was pictured with topless women and touring red-light districts on a holiday in Phuket, Thailand. The Sunday People at the time revealed the Duke of Yorkaposs new friends were nicknamed the NyLon Gang because they went between New York and London with no expense spared.  Among the people in the gang was Ghislaine Maxwell, who it was said took Prince Andrew to nightclubs and parties.An insider told the Sunday People back in : Andrew has been told in no uncertain terms that he must cut loose from this gang with all their drug links before it drags the reputation of the Royals into the mire. His behaviour is not that expected of the Duke of York and he has been told it must end right now. Andrew is laying himself open to exploitation and scandal and is becoming an appalling liability. What sort of example does he set to the rest of the world  Reports have said Prince Andrew went on tours of red-light sex clubs with billionaire paedo Jeffrey Epstein and holidayed with pimp Ghislaine Maxwell while in Thailand. In a set of infamous photos, the Duke of York played up to his Playboy Prince moniker when he was seen surrounded by topless supermodels partying on a yacht off the coast of Thailand seaside resort, Phuket. Maxwell and Epstein were said to have been on the same holiday as Andrew, with the former thought to have stayed at his hotel. And the manager of a venue in Patongaposs red-light district said he was graced with a regal visit when the British prince visited the topless go-go bar. The wild holiday, which took place in New Year in , was around the time Prince Andrew became close with the couple - and just months before he allegedly sexually assaulted Virginia Giuffre.  Andrew has vehemently denied this allegation and claims there was nothing improper about his relationship with the couple - who were both convicted of child sex crimes in the US. The Duke of York splashed out £,-a-night on a private villa at the lavish and ultra-exclusive Amanpuri Hotel in Phuket - where the couple also stayed, reports say. A Phuket-based journalist known as Lana told The Sun Online the resort is the go-to place for high-profile figures who need a high level of luxury and privacy.Spending his days on yachts with scantily-clad women, by night the Prince reportedly teamed up with Epstein to visit Patong - a notorious sex tourism hub where the streets are lined with go-go bars, massage parlours and other adult entertainment venues.  The pair visited the Banana Disco - a popular tourist nightclub which advertises itself online with videos of women wearing not much at all. The Queenaposs second son was said to have repeatedly visited a bar called Crazy Girls by Rock Hard, which is in a raunchy area where many of the girls are prostitutes.On Facebook, it says punters can enjoy the craziest and sexiest ass-smacking bar.Speaking to The Sunday Mirror at the time, the manager said: I was amazed to see the Prince here. But he was not at all fazed and seemed quite relaxed until people realised who he was.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Prince Andrew, Duke of YorkRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news inside-queens-private-farmhouse-retreat-"The Queen arrives at her Sandringham residenceByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments After staying at Windsor Castle for Christmas, the Queen has made an emotional trip to Sandringham to mark the th anniversary of her fatheraposs death.George VI died at Sandringham on February , , and the Queen almost always marks the day at the estate.But this time, rather than stay in the estateaposs big house, Her Majesty is believed to be staying at the private Wood Farm cottage. The farmhouse holds a special place in the Queen and her late husband Prince Philipaposs heart and her current stay is the first time sheaposs been there since Philipaposs death last April...Where is Wood Farm and what is its history Wood Farm is a five-bedroom cottage that is tucked away in a private part of the Queenaposs Sandringham estate in Norfolk. It is around two miles from the estateaposs main house and is said to have stunning view of the Norfolk coastline. When the Royal Family first bought the Sandringham estate in , it is believed that Wood Farm was already one of the buildings already on the grounds. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. In , it became the home of Prince John - son of George V and Queen Mary - who suffered from epilepsy and lived there with his nanny. After his death in  it was rented out.According to Vanity Fair, in the s Prince Philip took an interest in the cottage and began a renovation of it - decorating the walls in his artwork.He noted how it could accommodate the royals and their guests for short weekend trips, without the need to stay at the big house, which is expensive to run. Why does Wood Farm hold a special place in the Queen and Prince Philipaposs heart   The Queen and Prince Philip lived apart in the final years of his le, with the Duke of Edinburgh based at Wood Farm after he retired from public le while the Queen stayed at Buckingham Palace. However, she would regularly travel up to see him when she didnapost have engagements. The couple had only a small team of staff at the Farm, and they didnapost wear unorms as Philip didnapost like the formality.Former royal chef Darren McGrady once wrote on Twitter : I used to love it there. Itaposs so small you get to interact with them every day, rattle pans and play with the corgis! And when The Queen looks into the kitchen after a busy week and says aposThank youapos, you canapost get a bigger compliment than that. It is said the cosy nature of the cottage as well as its private location allowed the pair to be a normal couple. The Queen is believed to have sometimes cooked and done the washing up during her stays there. Meanwhile, Philip was said to enjoy his time there, tucked away from the other royals, reading, painting watercolours and having friends to stay. Other royals who have stayed at Wood Farm  However, it is not just the Queen and her late husband who have stayed at Wood Farm - many other royals have too as it is away from prying eyes.Before she married Prince William in , the Duchess of Cambridge would stay in the cottage while visiting the Sandringham estate. Similarly, Princess Diana is also said to have stayed there in the early s before her engagement to Prince Charles. Itaposs also where Sarah Ferguson was made to stay after her orce from Prince Andrew. She wasnapost allowed to attend the Christmas celebrations in the aposBig Houseapos at Sandringham, but wanted to be nearby to see daughters Princesses Beatrice and Eugenie.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON The QueenPrince Philip, Duke of EdinburghRoyal FamilySandringham" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: lovely dad two year old
story: Lovely dad and two-year-old son die in horror three-car collisionJohn Woodcock, , of Sutton-in-Ashfield, known as Dan to his family and friends, and his two-year-old son Lewis died in hospital following the collision in Mansfield earlier this monthJohn Woodcock, , and his two-year-old son, Lewis Image: Nottinghamshire Police   SWNSByJake Brigstock:,  Jan | commentsPolice have named the father and his two-year-old son who died in a crash involving multiple vehicles in Nottinghamshire.John Woodcock, of Sutton-in-Ashfield, known as Dan to his family and friends, and his two-year-old son Lewis died in hospital following the collision on Chesterfield Road North in Mansfield.The crash happened close to the junction with Pleasley Hill just after .pm on Saturday, January . Three cars are believed to have been involved in the incident as police continue to investigate what happened. Mr Woodcock and Lewis had already been named locally, and colleagues of Mr Woodcock, who ran Herbieaposs Hemp, a planet friendly waste shop within the Idlewells Indoor Market Hall in Sutton-in-Ashfield, have paid tribute.  The -year-old has been described as a aposlovely person and lovely characterapos. A fundraising page set up to help cover funeral costs has already surpassed its target. Detective Inspector Clare Gibson, of Nottinghamshire Policeaposs Serious Collision Investigation Unit, said: Our thoughts are with their family who continue to be provided with support by specialist officers at this dficult time. We continue to investigate the full circumstances and our appeal for information remains. Anyone who witnessed the incident or who has dash-cam footage is urged to please get in touch. The driver of one of the other vehicles was also taken to hospital where he remains. His injuries are not currently believed to be le-threatening.Anyone with information is asked to call Nottinghamshire Police on , quoting incident  of January  .Alternatively, they can call Crimestoppers anonymously on   . title: man 22 who couldnt swim
story: Man, , who couldnt swim drowns in sea while bravely trying to save friendIn the early hours after a night out, Alex raced to the seafront in Blackpool and got into the water after a friend called him and told him she didnt want to live anymoreAlexs friends said he had enjoyed going to Stanley Park in Blackpool to feed the birdsByAmy Fenton:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA brave man lost his le after drowning in the sea while attempting to save his friend who had gotten into trouble in the water. Alex Gibson, , had been on a night out with friends in Blackpool on Thursday, July  last year when the tragedy occurred. He had spent some time with his friend over the course of the evening but the pair separated when she went to Sapphires nightclub in the resort. In the early hours of Friday morning, Alexaposs friend called him from the North Pier and told him she didnapost want to live anymore. Alex raced to the seafront and went into the water to try and help her despite not being able to swim.An inquest at Blackpool Town Hall today heard that she got out and went for help but Alex was then found face down in the water less than an hour later, Lancs Live reported. Alex had met his friend while working at C Fresh Fish and Chips in Foxhall Road. Speaking at todayaposs inquest, she said: We were near the steps [to the right of the pier].  We were both in the water together. I was trying to help Alex because he couldnapost swim. We were hanging on to each other trying to keep each other afloat. I realised that the only way we were both getting out wassomeone got help so I told him that I was going to get out and get help. It took me a while to swim back because the current was really strong. After she managed to get out of the water she shouted back to Alex to tell him it would be okay. He was just trying to stay afloat, she said. I remember seeing him get further out. He was shouting for help. Mark Wright, who was sleeping rough in a shelter on the Promenade, said he was woken at .am when he heard Alexaposs friend screaming: Alex I canapost live without you. Giving evidence at the inquest, Mr Wright said he could see Alex struggling to keep his head above the water, but then lost sight of him because it was dark.  David Langton, who had also been asleep in a shelter, woke up when he heard Mark shouting to him: Get on your phone David thereaposs someone in the water. [Alexaposs friend] told me she wanted to kill herself, Mr Langton said in a statement. She told me her friend couldnapost swim. I tried to look for him but I couldnapost see anything. PC Ryan Kavanagh of Lancashire Police was driving down the Promenade at around .am on Friday, July  and pulled over when he saw Mr Wright at the side of the road. He asked meI was there because there was someone in the water, PC Kavanagh said.  I drove to the other side of the pier... below was [Alexaposs friend] near the wateraposs edge. She was covered in a blanket. She informed me she had been in the water, she didnapost want to be here anymore, and her friend had followed her to save her. She told me sheaposd kill herselfAlex was deceased. Leboat helmsman Sean Wright, who has volunteered with Blackpool RNLI for  years, was involved in the search for Alex. The crew spotted Alexaposs friendaposs white Primark handbag floating in the sea and  minutes later, at .am, found Alexaposs body face down in the water  metres from the shore. Alex was taken to Blackpool Victoria Hospital where resuscitation efforts continued but he was pronounced dead at .am. The medical cause of death was given as drowning with alcohol intoxication listed as a contributory factor. Dillon Dixon had known Bradford-born Alex for  years after the pair met at school and the two friends shared a house together. They had been out together on the Thursday night and Dillon had gone home at around pm. The following morning at .am, not knowing that his friend had just been declared dead, Dillon woke up and jokingly text Alex saying hope youaposre alive. Weaposve all jokingly sent similar after a night out, Dillon said.  The inquest heard Dillon, who had offered to take Alex to swimming lessons, thought of him as being like a brother and the two friends went through everything together. He was a proud vegan and had a heart of gold, Dillon said. He enjoyed going to Stanley Park to feed the birds. Alex has in the past had many dark thoughts and said he was tired of everything. He was always sad inside but had the biggest smile on his face. The inquest heard that although Alex had self-harmed in the weeks before his death and occasionally had dark moments there was no evidence he had deliberately taken his own le. Concluding that Alexaposs death was a result of misadventure - the unintended consequences of a deliberate act - Senior Coroner Alan Wilson said: Disregarding his own welfare, as someone who could not swim, this young man bravely went in the water and tried to save a vulnerable young girl. Anyone who has seen the tide at Blackpool when itaposs fully in knows it is dangerous. Itaposs most likely he got into dficulty pretty quickly and he was witnessed by someone trying to stay above the waterline. He could not survive. Alexaposs dad, who attended the inquest, said that he had wanted to place a permanent memorial to his son close to where he drowned. He added that Alexaposs colleagues have raised the money to install a bench in Stanley Park. After Alexaposs death his boss at C Fresh posted online: Alex was truly an amazing young man. All his friends would agree that he was intelligent, hardworking, pleasant, caring and literally wouldn’t hurt a fly. He is a true hero drowned sacricing his le to help another. He was loved by all his work colleagues and we miss him terribly. Tragically taken at . My heart goes out to all his family.AGoFundMeset up after Alexaposs death raised £, to help pay for funeral costs.The Samaritans is available  you need to talk. You can contact them for free by calling  , email jo@samaritans.org or head to the website to find your nearest branch. You matter. title: man who weighed 26 stone
story: Man who weighed  stone and scoffed  Double Deckers weekly drops  stone in a yearTobie Vermeire, , admits he would have ‘eaten himself to death’he had not made changes to his lestyleFood addict Tobie Vermeire, from Malvern Hills, Worcester, had always struggled with his weight Image: @obeseboxer Kennedy NewsByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Jan | commentsA -stone man who scoffed  Double Deckers every week until he was so obese he aposcouldnapost put his socks onapos has lost  stone in a year in a bid to become a professional boxer.Tobie Vermeire, , from Malvern Hills, Worcester, had always struggled with his weight but began to find himself eating a four-pack of the Cadburyaposs chocolate bars with lunch and sometimes more in the morning and evening.Each Double Decker contains g of sugar meaning Tobie was consuming a kilo of sugar a week just from the habit alone. For breakfast every morning, he would eat sausages, eggs and bacon for breakfast, two Dominoaposs pizzas for lunch and a Chinese takeaway for his dinner - along with more snacks. Wearing XXXL clothes and with a waist that stretched to  inches, Tobie - who was an insurance broker at the time - was left ‘shocked and embarrassed to discover his weight was  stone.He began his journey to change his lestyle in September , binning the daily fast food, chocolate and ice cream diet to focus on boxing.After just over a year, he has lost more than  stone and has set his sights on turning professional as a boxer by the end of the year. He admitted it was a tough journey and that he would have ‘eaten himself to death’he had not made the changes and shaken his addictions to ‘calories, grease, fast food’. Tobie said: “Iaposve always had a real issue with food. It was a comfort thing for me growing up and it continued through my adult le.  When I was , I was playing rugby at a reasonable level but whenever I got an injury and couldnapost play, I was still eating asI was training. I just got bigger and bigger. Around  I decided to focus on my career but this meant I let my health get even worse. I ballooned from  stone up to  stone. I couldnapost put my own socks on. As his weight grew, Tobie decided to dropdown the levels so he didn’t have to train as hard and could focus on his insurance broker job. He began to pay even less attention to his health and his daily diet saw him consuming up to , calories a day while he continued his desk job. He said: “I was a food addict. It was the only drive or pleasure in my le outside of working so food was my getaway. I was at work one day and they brought the scales out for everyone to check their weight. I thought I was going to be  stone and that I was just a few weeks off the weight I had been previously. When I stepped on them, I was  stone and I was just so embarrassed about how big I had become. I was wearing XXXL clothes and had a  inch waist so I was massive.I started to get really ill - I was fatigued, couldnapost get out of bed, constantly had headaches. I was tested for diabetes and thyroid problems but it turned out to be the physical signs of depression. In order to kick his addition to unhealthy foods and to lose weight, Tobie set about going cold turkey on his favourite foods. I had to treat it like a drug addiction and go teetotal on most of the foods Iaposd eaten before, so no chocolate, takeaways or crisps. I felt awful at first, really ill. I was having withdrawal symptoms for the first few weeks, which was me coming off the copious amounts of processed foods and chocolate Iaposd been used to. I was addicted to calories, grease, fast food, the whole lot. My diet was abysmal so I had to change. If I hadnapost, I think Iaposd have eaten myself to death. Iaposd like to think Iaposve added  to  years on to my le by reversing the years of destructive eating.” He said he turned to boxing because rugby wasn’t inspiring him anymore and he knew he had to try a new challenge. He said: “Iaposve always been a boxing fan and I decided I needed to set myself a goal that kept me on track. I decided to train to become a pro. “I looked for help from a few people but I realised I had to do it myself. Once Iaposd lost a little bit of weight and gained confidence, I joined a boxing gym and started working by myself on the heavy bags. It has just snowballed from there. Iaposve had a couple of amateur fights since covid restrictions have been loosened and Iaposve been sparring regularly with experienced pros.Tobie set up an Instagram and TikTok page to keep him accountable. “Iaposve never been happier,” he said.The only thing that I feel which is slightly negative is that I didnapost do it earlier. I feel bad that I let it get to the worst and didnapost change my le sooner. Itaposs been a huge year of change. Itaposs helped my mental health massively too. I left my job as an insurance broker to start selling motorbikes as Iaposve always loved them. I need to get some more fights under my belt before I can go pro as well as sorting some sponsorship for travel. ”I was meant to be fighting at the end of January but that has been delayed as I have had covid. Weaposre looking to get as many fights in as possible this season.Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Cadbury Ltd.Dominos PizzaFast foodIce creamMental healthChocolateWeight loss success stories" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
