title: 613 positive Covid cases in Downpatrick area last week
story: THE Downpatrick area recorded  coronavirus cases between January  and , the Department of Health has confirmed.Figures published on Monday revealed that there had been four more Covid-related deaths across the province and a further , positive cases, bringing the total number of positive cases to , since the start of the pandemic.Mondayrsquos figures also revealed that there were  Covid- confirmed patients in hospital and  in intensive care.The highest number of recorded Covid cases between January  and  was in the Newry and Warrenpoint area with , people testing positive.Dungannonand Derry and Dungivenwere in second and third place respectively in the Covid infection league table. Newry, with  cases, was in fourth place ahead of Derry .Downpatrickrsquos total of  cases mdash which placed the area in seventh place in the table ndash was  less thanNewtownards and seven more than Newtownabbey.The publication of the latest Covid figures came after Northern Irelandrsquos chief medical officer, Sir Michael McBride, issued a fresh call for pregnant women to get vaccinated.The warning comes as the spread of the Omicron iant continues to cause high case numbers in Northern Ireland with Sir Michael explaining that a recent study provides more evidence that having Covid- during pregnancy carries a far higher risk than having the vaccine, particularly in the later stages where it can have serious consequences for both mother and baby.ldquoCovid- vaccination is crucial in protecting women and babies from the le-threatening complications that can be associated with the virus, said the chief medical officer.ldquoldquoAnyone who is pregnant and has not received all of their vaccinations should not put off getting vaccinated until after their pregnancy.In addition to Sir Michael, a labour ward sister at the Ulster Hospital mdash managed by the South Eastern Trust mdash also urged all expectant mums to come forward to receive their Covid- vaccinations in light of a the study from the University of Edinburgh which found that women who get Covid- towards the end of their pregnancy are at an increased risk of birth-related complications.The study findings reveal that preterm births, stillbirths and newborn deaths are more common among women who have the virus  days, or less, before their delivery date.In addition, the study also provided further reassurance on the safety of vaccination during pregnancy.Sister Kate McGarrigle said it was crucial for all women to come forward and receive their Covid vaccination, especially in light of the highly transmissible Omicron iant.ldquoIf you do not receive your vaccine, you are at risk of becoming seriously unwell, she warned.ldquoReceiving the vaccine is the best way to protect yourself and your unborn baby. It is understandable that there are concerns around receiving the vaccine. Please do come forward and speak to your midwe or obstetrician and get information to allow you to make a decision.Vaccination clinics for first and second dose and booster jab vaccinations are available either by walk-in or appointment at the Downshire Hospital Great Hall in Downpatrick, the Ulster Hospitalrsquos acute services block or Lisburnrsquos primary care and community care centre.Further details on vaccination criteria and clinic times can be found on the health trustrsquos social media pages or by visiting the website www.setrust.hscni.net..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch centre  upgrade set to begin
story: WORK is expected to start shortly on a major internal upgrade at Ballynahinch Community Centre.Newry, Mourne and Down Council has drawn up plans to reconfigure the internal layout of the Windmill Street facility as part of a signicant investment initiative.Local people are being asked for their views on the planned upgrade which could be completed as early as the summer and cost in the region of pound,.Confirmation that work is to start soon on the centre upgrade has been welcomed by Rowallane councillor Kathryn Owen, who has also thanked Strangford MP Jim Shannon and her council colleague Billy Walker for their support in driving the renovation programme forward.She revealed that she had been contacted by a number of residents about the slow progress of the scheme and is pleased that everything is now on track.In addition to the planned work at the community centre, consideration is also being given to investing around pound, to finance internal alterations of the local authority-owned Market House in the town centre.And the Recorder understands that consideration is being given to providing an ultra-modern G sports pitch at the Langley Road playing fields with the adjoining sports pavilion also in line for a major upgradeA number of politicians have been lobbying for the local authority to address what they described as the organisationrsquos ldquounder investment in Ballynahinch and ensure that enhancing leisure facilities is a critical component of its future investment plans.Council officials had previously been asked to examine the potential of extending and upgrading the existing community centre at Windmill Street or a complete new-build, potentially on available land at the townrsquos Langley Road or at the Newcastle Road.However, they have opted to commit pound, on a major upgrade of the existing complex which will include a reconfiguration of the internal floorspace in a bid to increase the buildingrsquos usage.Politicians say they are keen to work in partnership with council officials and the Ballynahinch Community Collective to improve sports and community provision in the town to meet the needs of a wide range of people.Elected representatives say Ballynahinch needs to be at the heart of planned investment in future leisure provision across the Newry, Mourne and Down Council area.Politicians are keen to ensure that Ballynahinch does not miss out when it comes to leisure provision investment, given the money that has already spent in other towns across the council area.They believe that the good working relationship that exists between elected representatives across the Rowallane area can ensure that Ballynahinch does not miss out on future funding opportunitiesand that the needs of the townrsquos community are met, particularly when it comes to modern leisure, sports and community provision.Politicians want Ballynahinch to be included in any future strategy when it comes to leisure activities and provision, warning that the town cannot afford be left behind.They say the current community centre requires a much-needed upgrade with the current proposal a major step in the right direction.Elected representatives say that given the local council spend on major schemes in other parts of the district, the ratepayers of Ballynahinch deserve nothing less than an upgrade community centre and investment in other parts of the town..prettyPhoto

title: BBC Winterwatch TV show airs live from Castle Espie
story: THE Castle Espie Wetland Centre, near Comber, has been selected as one of three live locations across the UK to host BBC Tworsquos popular wildle programme, Winterwatch.Following on from the success of BBC Autumnwatch, wildle watchers are again coming to the shores of Strangford Lough.The programme began last night and will continue every weekday evening until Friday, January .Zoologist and conservationist Megan McCubbin, one of four presenters on the show, will shine a spotlight on this area of international wildle importance.Castle Espie, managed by the Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust , the UKrsquos leading wetland conservation charity, is home to over  acres of pristine wetland habitat filled with a range of wildle including rare and under threat species.A mixture of tidal lagoon, eel-grass mats, woodland, salt marshes and reed beds offer the perfect habitat for all sorts of wildle to thrive including a wide iety of water birds such as shelduck and shoveler and waders such as redshank, godwit and plover.Paul Stewart, Centre Manager at Castle Espie, said: ldquoWe are thrilled that the BBC watchers are ing to Northern Ireland and basing themselves at Castle Espie.ldquoWe are a centre for nature conservation, providing a window for the public on one of Northern Irelandrsquos great natural assets, Strangford Lough.ldquoCastle Espie is the only WWT wetland centre in Northern Ireland but we have global reach operating wetland centres and wetland focused restoration, conservation and protection in conjunction with local communities and governments across the globe.He added: ldquoOur work is shining a light on the importance of nature and the vital role that wetlands play for people and the planet which make us the perfect location for Winterwatch.ldquoI hope that the programmes presence at Castle Espie will encourage people both at home and further afield to value the wonderful natural capital we offer here on Strangford Lough..prettyPhoto

title: Broadband provider new fund for rural customers
story: FIBRUS has unveiled details of a new pound, fund to help people in rural areas in Downpatrick and Castlewellan to stay connected online.The telecommunications and broadband provider is working in partnership with the Community Foundation to award grants of up pound, to groups and organisations in rural locations over the next year to help them access digital technology and purchase equipment.The fund has a particular focus on supporting grassroots organisations that support older people and young people aged  and under.It has been confirmed that the community fund will operate in four phases in tandem with Fibrusrsquo programme to build new hyperfast full fibre broadband, with phase two including the Castlewellan, Downpatrick, Dromore and Dromara areas. Fund applications for these areas is now open.Mr Nicholas McCrickard mdash manager of the Co Down Rural Community Network mdash said the organisation very much welcomes the launch of the fund.ldquoAccess to the world of digital services is no longer a luxury, he continued. ldquoIt is becoming a necessity and people in rural areas are particularly vulnerable and with the ongoing closure of banks and other rural services, people very often have no option but to use digital devices.ldquoWe hope local groups in the Down area will make applications on behalf of older and younger people. We urge groups to think about how they can help rural residents and the Network is available to help with applicationsrequired.Community fund development manager Marcus Cooper highlighted the importance of keeping rural communities connected.ldquoCoronavirus has highlighted the need for communities to remain connected and many groups and charities working with those most vulnerable in our communities are telling us that a strong and sustainable broadband connection in rural communities is vitally important, he continued.ldquoThe pandemic has massively increased our use of technology and it now plays a vital role in our daily lives. Our learnings from Covid highlight digital poverty as a major concern in rural areas, negatively impacting isolation and loneliness, especially among young people and older people.Mr Cooper said the Fibrus Community Fund will support people in rural areas and begin to address the digital ide.Fibrus managing director David Armstrong said his company was committed to supporting the communities in which it operates.He continued: ldquoBy investing pound, through our new Fibrus Community Fund, we will be able to give back to some of the organisations doing wonderful work to enhance and support our thriving towns and villages across Northern Ireland.ldquoWersquore looking for projects specically aimed at young people who need greater access to technology or connectivity, as well as initiatives that combat digital exclusion amongst the elderly or those more vulnerable in our society.Mr Armstrong added: ldquoWe hope as many local groups and community organisations get involved and look forward to hearing more about peoplersquos good work.Groups or organisations who want to find outthey are eligible for the fund are asked to visit wwwmunityfoundationni.org for more information..prettyPhoto

title: Campaign over future of Down Museum heats up
story: OVER  people have expressed their concern over the future of Down County Museum in Downpatrick.They say the museum is under threat as a result of proposed cuts by Newry, Mourne and Down Council.In a letter in this weekrsquos Down Recorder, they say cuts in staff and resources will reduce the standard to a level below those required of a ldquoprofessional and dedicated museum.They say the council is proposing changes without proper public or political consultation.Of particular concern is the proposal to have one curator responsible for Down County Museum and Newry Museum, with that person to be based in Newry.A total of  people have signed the letter, including former South Down MP Margaret Ritchie, now Baroness Ritchie.Other signatories include distinguished academics, historians, artists, journalists and broadcasters, as well as members of the Friends of the Down County Museum, a charity which was set up over  years ago to provide support for the museum.In their letter they state: ldquoNewry, Mourne and Down District Council propose to make staffing numbers and resources diminish to a level well below the standard needed for a professional and dedicated museum responsible for the care of an extensive collection of artefacts that reflect the historical signicance not only of the county town, but of the region as a whole.ldquoWe are concerned about the lack of public or political consultation on these changes to the operational capacity of Down County Museum.ldquoInformation currently available suggests that this multi-award-winning museum will have no curator on site and a seriously downgraded curatorial and educational team to look after and display its collections, and to encourage their enjoyment by local people, community groups, schools and visitors.ldquoThe collections stored and exhibited in a series of historic buildings cannot be endangered through either carelessness or ignorance. And as well as their cultural signicance the implications for the economic and tourism attraction of the historic centre of the county are obvious.They add: ldquoWe call on Newry, Mourne and Down Council to halt its current direction of travel and demonstrate a commitment to restoring what was an internationally recognised centre of excellence in Downpatrick.ldquoWe ask it to respect its moral responsibility to honour the trust placed in the museum by those thousands of donors and friends who expected the council to cherish and support this public treasure house of the shared histories of County Down.Last week a spokesperson for the council said it was ldquocommitted to the continuous improvement and development of its museums.The spokesperson also said a meeting was held in December with stakeholders and elected representatives to clary there would be a reduction in ldquostaff head count following the restructuring.ldquoFurther engagement with stakeholders is planned for early this year and we look forward to working with all our partners to advance the councilrsquos ambitious and exciting plans for our museum services, the spokesperson added.See Letters on pages  and ..prettyPhoto

title: Down go under against Antrim
story: DOWN senior footballersrsquo disappointing start to their Dr McKenna Cup campaign continued when they lost out to Antrim by two points in Newry last week.The defeat means back-to-back losses for James McCartanrsquos new-look side, despite some encouraging inidual performances throughout from the Mourne outfit.Down will count themselves unlucky not to gain anything from the contest, having gone tit for tat with the Saffrons in the first half and Barry OrsquoHagan seeing his last gasp goal bound effort ricocheting over the bar instead of hitting the back of the net.McCartanrsquos men got off to a dream start when the newly ed Niall McParland sent a long ball forward into the hands of Ryan OrsquoHiggins, who opened the scoring through a well struck goal just three minutes in.Ruairi McCann and Odhran Eastwood confidently kicked over frees to bring Antrim within one point of levelling the scores before Packie OrsquoHagan doubled Downrsquos lead just before the  minute mark.Antrim did manage to completely reduce the deficit before the first water-break, with two quick-fire scores coming from Patrick McBride and a Pat Shivers free.As the players rehydrated, the surrounding supporters at Pairc Esler were awarded time to catch their breath as the fast paced game was momentarily brought to a halt.Veteran Darren OrsquoHagan entered the fray in the place of John McGeough upon the resumption before James Laverty kicked over a point from play to give the visitors the lead for the first time in the match.A well worked attack ended with Kevin McKernan levelling proceedings once again for the hosts, and soon after captain Caolan Mooney fired over between the sticks to give his side the advantage.Things began heating up in the cold weather, with plenty of firm challenges on show.Anytime the Mourne side were edging ahead, Antrim were right on their coattails and were now starting to overpower the home side in dferent areas of the pitch.Antrimrsquos McCann kicked over two unanswered points, the first from a rsquorsquo and the second from a free, although Downrsquos sharpshooting Barry OrsquoHagan restored parity in a matter of seconds.With three minutes to the interval, McCann converted his fourth free of the night to give the Saffrons a one point lead.Half time: Down - Antrim -.Down boss McCartan made his second change of the night in the form of Ross Carr swapping out Josh Connery to help give his county a dferent option at the back, although they conceded their first goal of the contest a minute into the restart.Patrick McBride duly converted a fisted effort past Downrsquos Rory Burns after Antrim team-mate Jamie McCann powered his way through the home defence.Down responded positively, splitting the sticks three times unanswered with scores from a Barry OrsquoHagan free and a brace of points from play through McKernan and Darren OrsquoHagan.After over ten minutes without a score on the board, Antrim finally kicked over the bar through Michael McCann.Causing further problems for Down, McCann proved important at both sides of the pitch when he managed to catch lsquokeeper Burnsrsquo attempted rsquo to rule out any chance of a goal.At the second water-break, the home side trailed by two with it all still to play for as both sides made changes.Barry OrsquoHagan took the mark and knocked over a brace of frees to level the scores but once again, Antrim would not be deterred and replied with a point from play by substitute Conor Murray.As the clock ticked down the next few scores would be vital in deciding the outcome and unfortunately for the home support they wouldnrsquot be given much more to cheer about.With two minutes of regulation time to go, Patrick McBride struck over what looked like an insurance point for the Saffrons.As the official announced three minutes of added time, Down pressed high in search of that crucial goal to share the points.With one last opportunity awarded to Down in the form of a free, Barry OrsquoHagan stepped up to fire his effort towards the net.However, the ball would have to travel past a sea of Antrim bodies that had smartly piled across the goal line.Agonisingly, OrsquoHaganrsquos effort smashed off the opposing Antrim wall of defence before clipping the crossbar on its way over to give the visitors a dramatic victory.Down: R Burns P Fegan, B McArdle, G Collins J Connery, N McParland, J McGeough A Doherty, L Middleton R OrsquoHiggins , C Mooney , C OrsquoRawe B OrsquoHagan , P OrsquoHagan , K McKernan Subs: D OrsquoHaganfor McGeough, R Carr for Connery, T Prenter for P OrsquoHagan. A Lynch for McParland, C Poland for McArdle, J Donaghy for McKernan, C Francis for MiddletonYellow card: A DohertyAntrim: O Kerr R Boyle, R Johnston, E McCabe P Healy, J Laverty , J McCann K Small, M McCannP McBride , P Shivers , R McCannJ Gribbin, O Eastwood , T McCannSubs: D McAleese for R McCann, P McCormick for Boyle, R Murrayfor Eastwood, C Murrayfor P Shivers, J McAuley for J McCann, D McCormick for T McCann, B McCormick for SmallYellow card: P McBrideReferee: M Farrelly ..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick’s Matthew dazzles in Dancing With The Stars
story: LOVE Island star Matthew MacNabb has waltzed himself into the next round of Dancing With The Stars on RTE One.A few days after coming out of isolation after having caught Covid, Downpatrick man Matthew and his professional dance partner, Laura Nolan, performed a Viennese waltz as the second couple to dance on Sunday eveningrsquos show.The marketing consultant danced to Dangerously by Charlie Puth for the dance which scored  points from the judges.After he finished,  year-old Matthew said: ldquoThis show requires skill, not just sitting around doing weights and talking to girls. Laurarsquos been amazing. Irsquom so thankful to her.New judge Arthur Gourounlian commented: ldquoI love a man who lives dangerously, yoursquore tall, dark and handsome. I wish yoursquod relaxed a bit more, enjoy it a bit more.Brian Redmond said of the dance: ldquoA bit slow in places, it didnrsquot have enough bite. Timing issues. Take the power, learn the timing. Frame needs a bit of work, sort that and timing, and it will be better.Loraine Barry praised Matthewrsquos effort and added: ldquoThe storyline was beautully played out. Yoursquove got to let go. Laura did well bringing in quick and slows. Tremendous effort for the first dance.Matthew came into the competition at a bit of a disadvantage, having just come out of isolation due to contracting Covid.Despite having missed out on precious practice time with his professional partner Laura Nolan, he was ready to push himself firmly out of his comfort zone.Speaking about his isolation, Matthew said: ldquoItrsquos been a bit crazy, but Irsquom doing the best I can. I was itching, I was actually practising the steps in my kitchen. Irsquom one of these people, when I do things I want to do them to the best of my ability.ldquoI thought, lsquoIrsquove got to push forward and do as much as possiblersquo. It actually helped me. I came back yesterday and that was the best I danced so far, thatrsquos what Laura was saying. So yeah, practice makes perfect.Matthew, who made a name for himself from his stint on Love Island over the summer, says hersquos ldquovery relaxed when it comes to practice.ldquoIrsquom very relaxed and Laurarsquos a bit of a panicker so we sort of balance each other out a little bit. I know when itrsquos time to work as well, he said. ldquoShe sometimes works and works and works and she doesnrsquot breathe. Irsquom like, lsquoBreathersquo. She really wants to do so well. Wersquove just got dferent methodologies.Regarding managing his nerves ahead of the show, he said: ldquoIrsquoll be nervous going out, but I wonrsquot be too bad. Whatrsquos the worst thatrsquos going to happen  If I fall and trip, I fall and trip. Irsquom not dead, you know what I mean  I would be disappointedI messed up because I really care and want to do the best possible, and Irsquove put a lot of work into it, but thatrsquos le. You can only control what you can control.Matthew said his competitive spirit will come to the fore as the competition continues.ldquoIrsquom absolutely in it to win it. I realised this a few years ago:I compare myself to anybody , I get in my mind too much and I get really angry, he explained.ldquoThe way I do it is I compare myself to who I was yesterday and it seems to work a lot better because I just work on my own thing and try to be the best version of myself.ldquoUltimately, Irsquom only competing against myself. The best I can do is the best I can do andthatrsquos enough to win the competition, then thatrsquos enough. If itrsquos not, then I canrsquot control that.Matthew is the son of local businessman Vincent MacNabb, who runs MacNabbrsquos waste management company, and his we Margaret.Until Dancing With The Stars, he had zero dance experience.ldquoI was exceptionally good on nightclub dance floors, Irsquom not going to lie, joked Matthew. ldquoNo, I have absolutely no dance experience whatsoever. I always say yes to every opportunity that comes my way. I can learn it mdash practice makes perfect.Matthew and the rest of the contestants will face the public vote this on Sunday at .pm on RTE One..prettyPhoto

title: Eight appliances tackle accidental early morning blaze at Newcastle pub
story: A FIRE at a popular bar in Newcastle last week was accidental, the Fire and Rescue Service believes.Firefighters extinguished the blaze at the Anchor Bar on the Bryansford Road during the early hours of Friday morning.It is understood that the blaze broke out just after am, with the Fire and Rescue Service deploying eight appliances to the incident.Crews from Newcastle, Knock, Downpatrick and Rathfriland responded to the emergency callwith footage posted on social media showing crews working at the scene of the incident overnight, with the Bryansford Road remaining closed as firefighters tackled the blaze.A Fire and Rescue Service spokesperson confirmed that firefighters were called to the fire in a non-residential property which had also spread to an adjacent building.ldquoFirefighters wearing breathing apparatus used four jets and an aerial appliance to extinguish the fire. The incident was dealt with by .am and the cause of the fire is believed to be accidental ignition.Local councillor Laura Devlin said she was ldquoshocked to learn of the fire at the Anchor Bar which she described as a ldquohuge part of the local community.She continued: ldquoIt is so much more than a pub and a restaurant. It represents so much good in the town between hosting pub quizzes and long standing charity work.The local politician praised the Fire and Rescue Service response and a local resident who raised the alarm.She added: ldquoThe damage to the bar and kitchen is signicant and major repair works are required. My thoughts are with Paddy, Rob and the fantastic team of staff at the Anchor. Letrsquos hope that work gets underway soon and the doors can reopen again soon..prettyPhoto

title: Exciting redevelopment of play park edges closer
story: IMAGES have been released of what the signicantly revamped Downs Road play park in Newcastle will look like when a major overhaul is completed by the spring.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is spearheading the overhaul of the hugely popular facility which is due to open in April.Designs for the new refurbished park, which have been made public this week, feature more inclusive play equipment to suit children of all abilities.When the upgrade is completed, park users will see a number of new additions, including the Newcastle Nautilus Play Galleon, swings mdash including one for those in wheelchairs mdash slides, a roundabout, sensory area, a trampoline and a zip wire.In addition, there will also be a new picnic area added which residents and visitors can enjoy when visiting the park and Newcastle Promenade.The refurbishment programme is part of the authorityrsquos play strategy which was established as a mechanism for meeting the play needs of children and young people throughout our district.Council chairwoman Cathy Mason says the Covid pandemic has made everyone more aware of the importance of outdoor activities andthe benefits that they bring to childrenrsquos physical fitness and mental health.ldquoThe councilrsquos play strategy plays a pivotal role in ensuring that children in our district have as many play opportunities as possible, she added.ldquoPlay is a natural, fundamental part of children and young peoplersquos lives that supports growth and development, enhances health and well-being, encourages social and intellectual development, and enables children and young people to develop essential le skills.Cllr Mason said she was delighted to see the refurbishment plans for the play park coming to fruition, ldquoin order that residents and visitors can enjoy the new inclusive facility once it reopens in the spring..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C  January 15%2C 1992
story: KILLOUGH ndash A gang of youths, who are responsible for an outbreak of vandalism in Killough, are believed to have burned a dog in their latest attack.Horried walkers along the villagersquos beach found the scorched body of the Jack Russell terrier near the harbour on Saturday morning and it is widely believed the youths are responsible.The RUC this week issued an appeal to the local community for anyone with information on the activities of this gang to come forward and assist the police.A police spokesman confirmed that the burned body of a dog, which had been reported missing by its owner, was discovered by walkers lying on rocks near the castle.He said the incident is the latest, and most horric, attack in an outbreak of vandalism which has shocked and sickened the community. So far the youths have engaged in wanton vandalism of ious areas of the village including putting dog faeces through letter boxes and damaging the villagersquos Christmas tree and festive lights last month.The RUC says it is vital that members of the public provide information which will bring an end of the vandalism problem.ldquoWe need the help of the community to bring those responsible to court, and without that help it will be very dficult to put an end to this problem, he said.BALLYNAHINCH ndash Management at the GPT telecommunications plant in Ballynahinch have pledged to work towards ensuring that it continues to have a future following the weekend announcement of  redundancies.The company, which manufactures hi-tech switching equipment for the telecommunications industry, revealed on Friday that it is to slice its workforce by more than half.The job losses will reduce the workforce at the Antrim Road plant to . Last July the figure stood at .The latest job announcement follows  voluntary redundancies at the factory in December.Fridayrsquos Ballynahinch job losses coincided with lay-offs at two other major industrial centres in the district ndash Killough brickworks stopped production for an indefinite period on Friday and there were further lay-offs in Killyleagh.The GPT Plessey workforce had been expecting lay-offs and there were even fears in some hurters that the cut-backs would involve the closure of the factory, operated by Plessey and now GPT for more than  years.But the Ballynahinch plant manager, Mr Gerry OrsquoNeill, said this week he was still hopeful about the plantrsquos future.ldquoThe Ballynahinch plant is the last in the company to announce job losses. The only good news is that we will not be closing and are hoping that a leaner and fitter plant can be a springboard for the future, said Mr OrsquoNeill.DRUMANESS ndash Around forty villagers from Drumaness rolled up their sleeves on Sunday to give the local mill pond a much-needed clean-up.The Friends of Drumaness Dam group pulled a large quantity of rubbish out of the pond in the first of a series of work days aimed at improving the area.Fallen branches which had been washed into the dam were removed with the aid of ropes, while rubbish dumped in the centre of the pond was removed by boat. The branches were burnt on a bonfire, and all plastic collected was taken to Drumnakelly dump for safe disposal.Among the workers who took part in the work day was Mrs Sheila Lewis-Crosby, who along with her husband John is the owner of the mill pond. She and Drumaness woman Mrs Carmel Mason cleared brambles constructing a path alongside the dam.After the clean-up, the secretary of the Friends of Drumaness, Dam Lisa Fagan, congratulated the volunteers and thanked local councillor Patsy Toman for initiating the venture.ldquoThe Drumaness people can be proud of our achievement here today, she said. ldquoThere is no doubt that the whole community is sickened by these incidents, he added.DOWNPATRICK ndash People who take part in the after-dark practice of ldquolamping rabbits have this week been warned they are placing themselves in danger.The RUC has warned that people who dress up in combat clothing and walk around fields hunting rabbits with firearms could find themselves being confronted by a security force patrol.Over the Christmas and New Year period, the RUC received reports of ldquolamping in the Downpatrick and Crossgar areas and it also believed to have occurred around Saintfield.The practice has been a problem in the Castlewellan area for a number of years but it is relatively unknown in east Down.It involves hunters going into fields without farmersrsquo permission and shooting rabbits by torchlight. Rabbits instinctively freeze when caught in a beam of light making them sitting targets for anyone with a shotgun.However, the sudden spread of the problem has alarmed the RUC which is appealing for people not to take part in what is regarded as a ldquohighly dangerous occupation.COMBER ndash Plans for the second stage of the Comber by-pass have been postponed for four years, it has been revealed.Strangford Ulster Unionist MP, Mr John Taylor, said he has been informed of the decision which he says has left him ldquoshell-shocked.ldquoTogether with local councillors and Comber businessmen I have been campaigning for many years to get the by-pass built. It is incredible that the Conservative Party is so mishandling the local economy that a scheme of such major importance to Comber and the outlying areas can be postponed to a date four years from now, Mr Taylor said this week.ldquoThe Minister met myself and a delegation of Ards Borough councillors last year and he agreed that Comber by-pass was a priority scheme Now he has shelved it for four years.ldquoI can understand slippage of a few months due to existing schemes costing more than has already been planned but a four year delay is out of the question.Mr Taylor said he has spoken to local members of his partyrsquos Comber branch and they are ldquohorried at the decision.BISHOPSCOURT ndash A total of around  local residents have signed a petition opposing proposals to turn the former Bishopscourt airfield into a motor-race track.The petition organisers say they are delighted by the response which indicates a ldquothumbs-down by the majority of people living in the area.ldquoThe residents all live in the immediate vicinity of the airfield or along the Downpatrick to Ballyhornan road, and so are the people most likely to be affectedthe planned track were to go ahead, explained a spokesman this week.The residents say they are concerned at proposals, currently with the Planning Service in Downpatrick, to turn part of the former air base at Ballyhornan into a race track.A spokesman said the petition is to be sent to the planning authorities and to the Minister for the Environment, Mr Richard Needham, this week. They are also to seek a meeting with planners to outline their case.SAINTFIELD ndash Damage to Saintfieldrsquos century-old floral farm cart at the weekend has infuriated village residents and especially the members of the pioneering Bloom committee.The celebrated cart, laden with polyanthus, pansies and spring flowers, had its shafts broken at the body when it was lted from its perch and ped to the ground before midnight on Saturday.In December it was removed to the side of the Orange Hall and behind locked gates to make space for the Christmas tree. It was due to be relocated on its traditional spot.Although noises were heard on Saturday night, the damage was not discovered until Monday morning when Mr Bob McCaughtry was preparing to open the Orange Hall for the weekly visit by Department of Health and Social Services personnel..prettyPhoto

title: Local derby is all square
story: A LARGE crowd gathered at the Demesne to watch the local derby which included Ballynahinchrsquos travelling faithful alongside the Saintfield home support.The first quarter began with both teams sitting back and waiting to see what their opponent was going to do.lsquoHinch started to play the ball from defence to midfield with Andrew Mulholland passing the ball to Scott Leetch, who was able to sht it out wide to apply pressure on Saintfield.Josh Higginson was able to create space down the left wing before passing to Matthew Martin at the top of the circle, only to be stopped in his tracks.Saintfield started to apply the pressure on lsquoHinch but they were halted in their attack down the right wing by defenders Hugo Melville and Leslie Harrison.They both displayed some outstanding tackling, which contributed to the opening minutes remaining goalless.The local rivals started to settle into the game after some quick instructions and soon passes began to link up nicely.As the game started to heat up, both teams were fighting for every ball and neither were sitting back. The competitiveness of the derby resulted in a stalemate by half-time.With chances coming early on into the third quarter, short corners naturally started to follow. lsquoHinch were able to work the ball up through Adam Dodds before passing over to Jason Campbell, who was able to win a short corner for his side.Matthew Martin released his drag flick going just wide of the post.Saintfield were able to keep lsquoHinch at bay until a cross ball from Martin found team-mate Andrew McIlwaine at the back post to opening the scoring.With lsquoHinch looking to keep their lead, they engaged a high press on to the Saintfield defence as they hoped to increase their lead.However, with this high press tactic Saintfield were able to break away past the lsquoHinch defence only to be met at the top of the circle by lsquokeeper Aaron Donnell, who did well to prevent a goal.A super ball from Leslie Harrison to forward Lewis Higginson, allowed the lsquoHinch attacker to run the baseline and win a short corner.Martin took a drag flick only to be stopped by the Saintfield lsquokeeper.Saintfield responded by pushing lsquoHinch into their own circle and winning a short corner.The Saints managed to convert off the short corner to equalise the game in the final quarter.Despite a few more half chances, both sides went home with a share of the spoils..prettyPhoto

title: Magnificent Kilcoo are champs of Ulster again
story: KILCOO are one game away from a place in this yearrsquos All-Ireland Club Championship final.Last Sunday, the Magpies produced a spectacular performance to dismantle Fermanagh champions Derrygonnelly at the Athletic Grounds in a one-sided affair to win by  points.Mickey Moranrsquos men are now red-hot favourites to win the All-Ireland club final after losing out to Galway champions Corofin after extra-time in .But Kilcoo must first overcome St Finbarrrsquos in the semi-final clash at pm on Saturday, January  at OrsquoMoore Park, Portlaoise and will be taking nothing for granted.Last Sunday, goals from Daryl Branagan, Ceilum Doherty and Shealan Johnston contributed to the onslaught in Armagh to secure the Ulster title by a comfortable margin.Paul Devlin enjoyed his afternoon splitting the sticks, with reassurance within the squad stemming all theway from the back through Kilcoo lsquokeeper Niall Kane, who bossed hisarea and even registered a point of his own.With the pain of the  All-Ireland defeat still hurting, Kilcoo will be looking to right that wrong and taste success.ldquoThe Corofin game really hurt, said Kilcoo star Ryan McEvoy.ldquoAfter playing so well for so long and then just not getting over the line, it hurt. Coming back into the   season, we had a job to do, to win Down and we took it game by game. Unfortunately, the Ulster Championship last year wasnrsquot on, he continued.ldquoThis year was all about winning Down and winning Ulster and, hopefully, going on to win an All-Ireland.Originally priced at  , Kilcoorsquos powerhouse  of players have jumped to   top picks, with their All-Ireland semi-final opponents St Finbarrrsquos heavy outsiders at  .The Cork-based outfit are the biggest underdogs left in the competition according to bookmakers, with other semi-finalists Kilmacud Crokes and Padraig Pearsersquos priced at   and  , respectively.Ahead of the semi-final, McEvoy said ldquoitrsquos a big opportunity.He continued: ldquoYour dream is to be playing All-Ireland semi-finals All-Ireland finals year in, year out. We just deal with it one game at a time and we will worry about St Finbarrrsquos now.ldquoExperience is key. We have been there and we know what to expect, but we donrsquot know much about St Finbarrrsquos as we have never played them.The Kilcoo star added: ldquoWe will just sit down and focus on them and take it from there.There will perhaps be an unusual link in familiarity within the St Finbarrrsquos ranks, as former Down county star Conor McCrickard is part of their starting .The  year-old made the switch down south last year as part of a biomedical engineering degree at Ulster University and enjoyed an incredible debut season with The Barrrsquos, having contributed to their Cork Senior Football Championship win against Clonakilty and most recently, their Munster title victory over Austin Stacks.The Liatroim Fontenoys clubman will hold valuable know-how over his neighbouring club Kilcoo, and may use this unlikely  to give newly reinstated Down boss James McCartan a selection headache for the future..prettyPhoto

title: Radio show to talk about Burns Night
story: BURNS Night takes centre stage on the Chris Scott Show on FM Down Community Radio tonight from pm.Join Chris in conversation with Brian Cassidy, president of the Belfast Burns Association.Brian talks to Chris about some aspects of the le of Robert Burns, the world famous Scottish poet and lyricist.Brian also talks about the Belfast Burns Association and what happens at a Burns Night, which will celebrated world-wide on January , Burnsrsquo birthday.Chris will be playing some of the bardrsquos compositions throughout the show.The programme is repeated on Sunday, from -pm If you are outside the FM signal area you can tune in online at https:onlineradiobox uk downcommunity You can also go to the Google Play Store and App Store and download the SERC Community Radio app..prettyPhoto

title: Saintfield community park could be reality as US benefactor visits
story: AMBITIOUS plans for a new heritage community park in Saintfield could finally come to fruition in the spring of , it has been revealed.Saintfield Development Association is spearheading the drive for the new facility on land known locally as the Windmill Field, adjacent to the new community centre at the Belfast Road.A bid for funding to help pave the way for the new park, which is also being financially supported by American benefactor David Moffett whose ancestors emigrated to the USA from nearby Leggygowan, has been submitted to the National Lottery Heritage Fund.It is hoped that a decision on the funding application will be made by March.The application includes a proposal to stabilise the three remaining stone buildings at the site of the proposed park and make them safe for future generations to visit and learn about the industrial heritage of two windmills, two watermills and railway.In the latest edition of Saintfield News, the association described progress with the planning application for the proposed community park as ldquoslow, but steady.The application is seeking permission for a change of use from agricultural to amenity use for the public. All statutory consultees bar one have now given the proposal their approval, with discussions with the final consultee in progress.Association officials say the planning application covers only the paths, pond, fencing and information  associated with the field close to the community centre.ldquoMany hours have been put in completing the application to the Heritage Fund which was submitted at the end of November with a decision due in March, Saintfield News confirms, explaining thatthe bid is successful, it will be for the development phase of the project.ldquoThis will probably take one year and will include detailed measurements of the scheduled monument buildings, work plans, costings for stabilising these and obtaining scheduled monument consent and planning approval for these works.ldquoAt the end of this development phase a further application to the Heritage Fund would be made for the delivery phase of the project. ldquoThe association says thatthis was successful and all went well, the park and windmill would be opened to the public in the spring of .However,the Heritage Fund application is unsuccessful, the association will proceed with the proposal, but the work would exclude the scheduled monument area.ldquoThis would be fenced off as unsafe and left as is, reports Saintfield News. ldquoCompetition for Heritage Fund grants is very competitive and many other projects in Northern Ireland will be applying. It will be a great achievementwe are successful.ldquoThis is probably the only source of funding that can preserve the windmill and the other two buildings of the scheduled monument for future generations. Without this funding, the buildings will continue their slow decline and will eventually collapse.Meanwhile, the man who is supporting the community park proposal visited Saintfield recently.Mr Moffett has already made a substantial donation to the association to enable it to purchase the Windmill Field.During his visit, Mr Moffett had an opportunity to walk around the field and visualise how the proposed community park would surround the ancient windmill and caretakerrsquos home that is part of Saintfieldrsquos history. He also met a number of residents at the community centre before visiting Rowallane Garden for a guided tour.Mr Moffett concluded the first day of his visit with a visit to the Belfast Road community centre to view the new facility and was impressed at the potential of fitting out the remaining empty buildings which would include a heritage area to complement the planned windmill park.Mr Moffett, who also played a round of golf at Royal County Down and visited the Mournes, said the beauty of Co Down, with its unique visitor sites and the central location of Saintfield, reinforced in his mind the importance of the windmill park project and the heritage centre.The third and final day of his visit was spent at a local shop exploring the location of his familyrsquos th century farm in Leggygowan.Mr Moffett said: ldquoExploring my family history was a wonderful way to end my visit to Saintfield. I look forward to ing soon and continuing to work on our shared interest in completing the windmill park project and heritage centre..prettyPhoto

title: Speed sign reinstated in Saintfield in bid to halt speeding drivers
story: WORK has started to reinstate an electronic speed indicator sign at the Ballynahinch Road in Saintfield.The sign mdash one of a number erected across the district by the arearsquos Policing and Community Partnership mdash was removed last year after concerns were expressed about its original location at the busy road.Designed to put the brakes on speeders, the signs have proved effective in a number of locations with plans to install more of them over the coming months.The reinstatement of the Saintfield sign has been welcomed by Rowallane councillor Kathryn Owen, who said that it will make drivers more aware of their speed at this busy road.A decision to relocate the Saintfield sign was agreed by a sub-committee of the districtrsquos Policing and Community Safety Partnership.Cllr Owen said she was delighted that the speed sign was being erected as it will remind drivers of their speed as they approach the built-up town centre area.Cllr Owen also thanked residents who helped her lobby for the reinstatement of the speed indicator sign following its removal.The Ballynahinch Road is one of the districtrsquos speeding hot spots with a number of high speeds recorded by the previous speed indicator sign located in a mph zone. It was revealed last May that one driver was clocked travelling at an incredible mph in the mph zone in Saintfield at am.Figures released by the PCSP over the past year have revealed that speeding in built-up areas across the district continues to be a major problem.In addition to the Ballynahinch Road in Saintfield, other speeding hot spots include the Strangford Road in Downpatrick and South Promenade in Newcastle.The Dundrum Road in Clough is a new entry on the list following the installation of an electronic speeding device on the approach to the village, while the Downpatrick Road in Ardglass is another new entry on the speeding hot-spot list.The highest speed recorded in the mph zone in Clough was mph at am, with the highest speed at the Strangford Road mdash where a mph limit is in place mdash was mph. This offence was detected around am.Since the speeds recorded by the electronic devices have been made public, politicians have expressed their shock at the behaviour of those who continue to break the law and have appealed to them to slow down.Erected as part of a major offensive on speeding drivers at a number of well known speeding hot spots, the speed indicator devices are being hailed a success as speeds in most areas where they are located are reducing.However, concern remains about the behaviour of some drivers continuing to show a blatant disregard for mph and mph speed limits in place.Recent figures published by the PCSP revealed that the highest number of speeders in Castlewellan and Killyleagh were detected around am and pm respectively, with those who hit high speeds in Ardglass detected at pm.While Clough recorded the highest speed, a detailed examination of the figures reveals that five drivers went through the mph in the village at mph, with % of all drivers travelling in excess of the speed limit.In Downpatrick,  drivers were detected at over mph in the mph zone, with one driver clocked at mph in the mph zone at the Dublin Road in Castlewellan. The highest speed recorded at the mph zone at the Downpatrick Road in Ardglass was mph.Policing and Community Safety Partnership officials say that figures recorded across the districtrsquos speed indicator signs for the most recent three-month period shows an overall speed reduction of around six percent.The number of drivers clocked at over mph across the  speed indicator signs spread across the Newry, Mourne and Down Council area was almost , while the average number of speeding violations over mph was %. The average number of speeding violations over mph in mph zones was almost %..prettyPhoto

title: burns night where to join in the celebrations around northern ireland
story: PSNI: Two men killed in road traffic collision   Doug Beattie says sorry for Edwin Poots brothel ‘joke’NewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsNationalBurns Night: where to join in the celebrations around Northern IrelandNorthern Irish musician Rachel Hutchinson has given Robert Burns’ poems a contemporary twist as part of the Ulster Scots Agency’s Burns Week celebrations.By Graeme CousinsMonday, th January , : pmUpdated Monday, th January , : pm  "       "  Jacqueline Purse, digital marketing officer with the agency said that due to ongoing restrictions at the time of planning, activities had to move online for . New digital content will be shared across the Agency’s social media channels every weekday and the videos focus on Burns’ work and his links to the city of Belfast and beyond.Videos include local singer and musician Rachel Hutchinson performing works from Burns including ‘Ae Fond Kiss’ and ‘You’re Welcome, Willie Stewart’.    " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Matthew Warwick, education officer with the Ulster-Scots Community Network, will deliver a short informational piece, aimed towards children, looking at Burns’ famous Auld Lang Syne and the meaning behind the words. In addition, the Agency will share a video which outlines how the Scottish poet came to be known as ‘Belfast’s Bonnie Burns’. The videos will be available to view via the Ulster-Scots Agency’s Facebook page, YouTube channel, and Discover Ulster-Scots app. Other Burns Week activities to note include The Andrew Gibson Memorial Lecture , with Alistair Heather, hosted by Linen Hall Library which took place yesterday but will be made available to view later via the library’s YouTube channel. Addressing the Haggis. INCR-PLFunded by the Ulster-Scots Broadcast Fund, Paula McIntyre’s Burns Night Banquet aired on BBC Two NI on Sunday and is now available to watch on BBC iPlayer. The Schomberg Society, based in Kilkeel, are also hosting a Burns Festival, which runs until Saturday. Jacqueline said: “Burns Night is an important date in the Ulster-Scots calendar and while we may not be gathering together in the same manner or numbers as in previous years we are delighted that through a iety of partnership arrangements the Ulster-Scots Agency continues to be able to help promote and explain the linguistic and cultural links between Scotland and Ulster and our shared love of the enduring works of the Scottish Bard, Robert Burns.”Meanwhile in Ballynahinch tomorrow nightat the Hinch Distillery a Burns Night supper with a twist is taking place.The bistro is fully booked for  people for a celebration of the traditions and culture exchanged over the centuries between the Scotch and Irish people.It will feature a masterclass tasting of fine Scotch and Irish Whiskey paired with haggis, neeps and tatties.Poetry will come courtesy of Matthew Warwick and music comes from piper Graham Harris and Campbell College band in the courtyard.——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: it is perhaps best to answer humour however tasteless with humour
story: Protestants should not say sorry for abuse in Catholic establishments   Doug Beattie says sorry for Edwin Poots brothel ‘joke’NewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionIt is perhaps best to answer humour, however tasteless, with humourA letter from Simon Dilworth:By LettersTuesday, th January , : amUpdated Tuesday, th January , : am  "       "  The late Ian Paisley found himself at the receiving end of a joke about prostitution at WestminsterA recenttweet posted by Doug Beattie  has made unfortunate headlines for the Ulster Unionist Party leader. But this is not the first time a DUP representative has been on the receiving end of a joke concerning prostitution .In the late s a crowded House of Commons saw a debate on the legalisation of prostitution. Ian Paisley Senior had something to say on the matter.    " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Letter to the editorIn his flamboyant eloquence he guldered: “If this House gives prostitution the green light ...” He didn’t get finishing his sentence as the chamber erupted with exaggerated laughter and shouting. The honourable member for North Antrim waited until order was restored, then retorted with “If you gentlemen know the colours of prostitution please forgive my ignorance”.Society and the political landscape has changed since then, but perhaps humour, however tasteless, should be answered with humour. The fake dismay and consequential political point scoring annoys more than any politician auditioning for Saturday Night Live.Yours trying to keep a straight faceSimon Dilworth, Dungannon——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. It comes in behind Pembrokeshire at first place with  beaches, Devon with , Cornwall with  and Anglesey with .The research comes as people are looking to continue to holiday at home as Wales and the UK begins to re-open and international travel is still looking unsure. It was carried out by Uswitch and can be viewed here: https:www.uswitch car-insurance guides uk-dog-friendly-beaches-mapped In their list of  beaches from across the UK, Ogmore Beach comes in third place behind Cayton Bay in North Yorkshire and Oxwich Beach near Swansea.MORE NEWS:Coronavirus: One in three adults in Wales now fully vaccinatedDream seaside home has seven bedrooms and an amazing al-fresco entertaining areaLaurence Llewellyn-Bowen joins campaign to transform oldest Vale homeThe Uswitch guide says that Ogmore Beach is best for fishing, walking and dog-friendly pubs and the car park costs £ a day, with dogs allowed on the beach all-year round and there are no restrictions. They say that the beach is a sand and shingle beach and has a reputation for being one of the cleanest in the region. There is a coastal walk, chance to go fishing, surfing and views of Tusker Rock.For those owners who may not yet have ventured to the beach with their pups or are concerned about behaviour while at the beach, Wood Green’s dog behaviour and training specialist, Wendy Kruger, has provided some tips to prepare your dog for the beach.• Ensure your dog’s microchip and collar tag details are up to date – just in case.• Get used to checking ground surface temperatures before you take your dog out, as dry sand can be too hot for dogs’ paws on sunny days. To check the ground temperature, place the back of your hand on the ground. If its too hot to hold comfortably for five seconds, it’s too hot for dogs’ paws..remove• Practise basic, reward-based training when out and about to help your dog to maintain focus and engagement on walks.• Recall is also an area that needs particular attention. Evenyour dog has a great recall at home, its not something that can be guaranteed in unfamiliar environments with exciting new distractions. Games with toys are a fantastic way to help your dog engage with you when there are other distractions around. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: vale author details history welsh pubs new book
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityGraham Loveluck-Edwards has announced the release of his new book Historic Pubs of Wales where he relishes in some of the more colourful myths, legends and stories from Wales ancient past and oldest pubs. Included in the book is The Captains We, in Sully, a house originally owned by a captain. "I have always loved old pubs, and we are blessed to have so many belters here in Wales," added Mr Loveluck-Edwards. Graham Loveluck-Edwards out snapping some pubs for his book"For example, the pub which claims to have an elephant buried under its beer garden, or the pub where funeral parties take a short cut to the cemetery through the bar to keep an ancient right of access alive, or the pub that claims to have invented pancake day and so many more. "In all, Ive compiled over  incredible stories based around  amazing old pubs - is there any truth to them "Some for sure, but this book captures them and puts them in the context of history so you can be the judge."MORE NEWS:The book also contains a travel guide so readers can go on a tour around Wales and visit all the pubs in the book.You can find out more at www.talesfromhistoricpubsofwales.  The book is available to buy now"As you can imagine for such a book the research was relentless and thorough, and a lot of fun," he added."Pubs have had such a tough time in the last year with us going in and out of lockdowns and with the introduction of social distancing measures. "Sixteenth century inns are usually a warren of tiny rooms so being two metres apart has made opening and trading near impossible for many. "So, a book which celebrates all that is great about our old pubs, which tells people their history, where to find them and what to expect when you get there has been welcomed by all landlords." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - title: cardiff city boss welsh covid  regulations
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityAll sporting events in Wales will be held behind closed doors from Boxing Day due to the surge in coronavirus cases, the Welsh government has announced.Cardf CEO Mr Dalman insisted all new guidelines will be followed, but conceded another shut-out of fans will hit the Bluebirds hard.“It’s a major blow from all aspects, but we have to put the safety of our fans, players and everyone first,” Mr Dalman told talkSPORT.“So we will follow the guidelines as they are laid out.“These things are made for a reason and as much as we dislike them, we will certainly obey them.“It’s a blow of course for football, a blow for our club, because we always want to play in front of our fan base, and that’s a great shame.”Fans of Welsh football clubs should currently still be able to attend away matches in England, but Mr Dalman feels further restrictions may be in the offing.AskedCardf fans could travel to away matches in England, Mr Dalman replied: “Theoretically speaking that’s correct, in practical terms, let’s see what happens next.“There are a lot more developments to come, I’m sure of that.“So I would just wait to see the next announcements from the government as to the guidelines, and we go from there.”When askedthe EFL would be able to prise any money out of the Premier League to help offset lost revenue, Mr Dalman replied: “You know my views on the EFL, the answer is I wouldn’t hold my breath.”Economy minister Vaughan Gething announced the new measures for indoor and outdoor sporting events in a bid to slow the spread of the Omicron iant.Mr Gething said: “Sporting events over the Christmas period are one of the big highlights of the year. Unfortunately, the new Omicron iant is a signicant development in the pandemic and could cause a large number of infections..remove“We need to do everything we can to protect people’s health and control the spread of this awful virus.“Throughout the pandemic we have followed scientic and public health advice to keep people safe. The advice is clear – we need to act now in response to the threat of Omicron. We are giving people as much notice of these decisions as we can.“Crowds will come back as soon as possible. We want everyone to be here to enjoy their favourite sports.”Cardf’s United Rugby Championship clash with Scarlets and Wrexham’s National League fixture against Solihull – both scheduled for December  – will be the first affected by the ruling.And the Welsh Grand National at Chepstow will also have to be run behind closed doors despite advance ticket sales in excess of ,.Cardf City’s Championship clash against Coventry has already been postponed due to a coronavirus outbreak in the Bluebirds’ camp, as has the URC game between the Ospreys and the Dragons.The first EFL fixture due to be affected is Swansea’s Championship clash with Luton, which is currently scheduled for December .Cardf City said in a statement: “Cardf City Football Club acknowledges the instruction from the Welsh government for sporting events in Wales to be played behind closed doors for a limited period of time in an effort to curb the spread of the Omicron iant.“Following the postponement of our Boxing Day fixture with Coventry City on Monday, this is set to most immediately impact our FA Cup third round tie with Preston North End on January th.”Gething confirmed that a £million spectator sports fund will be available to support those clubs affected by the loss of spectator revenue.Chepstow racecourse chief executive Phil Bell anticipated the move last week, when he told BBC Wales: “We’ve seen this coming in recent days.“It would be damaging. We’ve currently sold , tickets – an average price £ — so people can do the maths. Around  people have booked hospitality packages at around £ to £ – there are signicant amounts of revenue at stake here.” article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: welsh nightclubs sports venues can reopen
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityAddressing the nation earlier today , first minister Mark Drakeford revealed that the recent measures put in place in an attempt to stop the spread of the Omicron iant of covid have helped "flatten the curve of infections".This, coupled with efforts to provide every fit and healthy person with an invitation to get their booster vaccine, has allowed the Welsh Government to put plans in place to loosen restrictions once again.The news is likely to come as a welcome piece of news for sports organisations and hospitality venues in Newport, Gwent, and the wider region.Since mid-December, restrictions have been placed on crowd numbers at sporting venues, which all but forced games to be played behind closed doors.As for hospitality, nightclubs have been closed in Wales since December , and while these traders missed out on a potentially lucrative payday on New Year’s Eve, they are now just weeks away from being able to reopen.Nightclubs reopening in Wales: Everything you need to knowFrom Friday, January , nightclubs in Wales will be able to reopen to the general public once again.As part of this, the rule of six, two-metre physical distancing requirements, and table service at pubs and restaurants will no longer be mandatory.Ahead of reopening, venues, along with all businesses and employers are required to undertake a covid specic risk assessment, to take reasonable measures to prevent the spread of the virus.And, as before, anyone looking to attend a nightclub will have to provide a covid pass as a condition for entry.What we know as fan restrictions at sporting venues ltedSports fans in Wales won‘t have to wait as long as the nightclubs toto their haunts, with restrictions on crowd numbers set to be lted on January ..removeNationally, this will be a major boost ahead of the Six Nations, but locally, it means that Newport County and the Dragons will be able to welcome fans back to Rodney Parade.The Dragons will be the first of the local sides to be able to allow fans back in, when Italian side Benetton arrive on January , before the posts are swapped out, and County welcome Barrow the following day.No limits will be placed on outdoor activities, but as before, covid passes will be required to attend games with a large scale crowd expected.What has been said about the changes Confirming news of the upcoming rule changes, Mr Drakeford said: "We able to do itonly because of the amazing hard work and effort of everyone  who have once again followed all of the rules and taken all of the steps to keep ourselves and our loved ones safe."The enormous efforts of all those working in the vaccination centres, in our NHS, in our public services, in shops and in businesses who have done so much to protect us fom this latest wave of that awful virus."Thank you - thank you to everyone who has done so much to help to keep us safe."It doesnt mean the pandemic is over." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey title: penarth ramblers group walk knap
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityLast year because we were in deep lockdown it never happened and because of the current Covid rules it had to be postponed again, which is probably why only three walkers came out to meet him at the Knap car terrace in perfect walking weather, on a bright and crisp morning to join in a -mile replacement walk.On the hillside just above them are the neat foundations of a Roman Building which contained  rooms all grouped around a courtyard with the building being dated to the late rd century AD by the Glamorgan-Gwent Archaeological Trust. It seems a natural harbour was to be found to the east of this area and one theory is that this was a guesthouse connected with naval activity at the harbour as no evidence of a water supply or baths common in villa’s could be found. In the early ’s the trust carried out excavations on site and pieces of Roman pottery and tiles were found and a public viewing  now overlooks the site.They soon warmed up due to a short but stf climb onto the clftop and followed a narrow path through woodland to descend the Golden Stairs into Porthkerry Country Park, where the frost covered board walk led them towards the ft Porthkerry Viaduct. Deviating off the cycle path at Robin’s Walk brought them into muddy fields beside the Whitelands Brook for the climb up to join the A opposite Welford and along the verge to cross a stile leading into fields behind Blackton Farm.A well-worn farm track led to the road for the journey to Penmark Village where they entered the churchyard of St Mary’s for their mid-morning refreshments, utilising the steps on the preaching cross as seating whilst enjoying the warm sunshine. The church dates to the th century being mentioned for the first time in  and a few centuries later the tower was added, but most of its medieval traits were lost when it was renovated during the Victorian era..removeThey continued and joined part of the long distance Valeways Millennium Heritage Trail, through fields on the boundary of Cardf Airport making towards Fonmon with its lovely duck pond and stunning weeping willow tree which cascades over the water. Then climbing steps into a small wood leading to muddy fields near Home Farm they eventually exited onto Port Road following it southwards to East Aberthaw.Taking time out they paused at the Blue Anchor for a swt pint outside in the fresh air before following Well Road downhill. This road was previously known as Marshe Way, one would presume because the River Thaw flowed to reach the sea by this route until the Aberthaw Power Station was built and the river was re-routed.Tramping muddy paths below the main Vale railway line through the nature reserve which is classed as a Site of Special Scientic Interest, they headed through the reed beds beside the western end of the delightful lake, overseen by the ruined Aberthaw Limeworks built in , to arrive at the sea defence wall. Heading out onto the beach they found a suitable place for lunch sitting on a washed up tree trunk beside the dunes and overlooking the Bristol Channel and English coastline before continuing along the salt flats.The beautul refurbished clf steps on part of the Wales Coast Path brought them steeply uphill into Fontygary Leisure Park, which was eerily quiet due to the winter months and reaching Fontygary beach, they continued up steps following the coast path past the old disused limestone quarries to reach the southernmost tip of mainland Wales and Rhoose Point. Onward through Porthkerry Holiday Park and the Iron Age hillfort at the Bulwarks, to slither downhill through the woods back into Porthkerry for the steep climb back up the Golden Stairs in order to make their way along the clftop to Cold Knap, just as the sun was sinking in the western sky.You can follow the group’s exploits at www.penarthramblers.wordpress or Facebook article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: view senedd
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityI WANT to send my best wishes to all of the students and pupils ing to school and college this month.I welcome the £m announced by the Education Minister Jeremy Miles MS when term started last week to help make schools and colleges more Covid secure and environmentally friendly.I also welcome the additional £m he announced to support learners with ALN to recover from the effects of the pandemic.It is also great to see the joint investment of the Vale of Glamorgan Council and Welsh Government in the new Pencoedtre High School which opened its doors recently with the ‘state of the art’ st century facilities I saw when I visited last year with Councillor Lis Burnett.Next month the new members of the Welsh Youth Parliament will meet for the first time. Young people in Wales had the opportunity to elect their youth representatives in November .By participating in issue based politics, children and young people will get to experience first-hand how politics works and the direct effect it can have on their lives.I would like to congratulate those elected from the Vale of Glamorgan. Evie Kwan represents the Vale.Dan Downton was elected as a partner member on behalf of the National Deaf Children’s Society. Seth Burke represents Ty Hafan.I want to wish Seth who has recently recovered from Covid well and I look forward to meeting with everyone over the next few months.In this year’s Local Government elections, which will be held in May,    year olds will be able to vote for their local councillors for the first time.It is so important that young people engage with politics and are given the opportunity to voice what is important to them and influence decisions which effect them. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues.
